No DAC, fully analog nulling + TIA. # Final recommended architecture (short) **Analog coarse VI (pot) TIA summing node analog fine integrator servo (VI)** **High-value feedback resistor TIA (100 M)** **Low-noise buffer/subtractor ADC** (ADC only for digitization/record; nulling loop is analog). This preserves DC (you will know absolute residual after nulling) and gives ~**10 mV per 100 pA** (good for measurement). # Block-by-block description (with suggested parts & reasons) 1. **Coarse analog current source (manual coarse) VI** * Purpose: remove the bulk of the 755 A baseline so the TIA amplifier doesn't saturate. * Implementation: precision reference (Vref = +2.5 V) multi-turn pot (coarse adjust) precision op amp in voltage-to-current topology feeding summing node. * Suggested op amp (coarse driver): **OPA4H199-SEP** (space/rad-hard driver) or similar rad-hard driver with good drive and stability. * Suggested resistor for VI: **R_coarse 2.49 k** at Vpot = 2.49 V gives 1 mA full range (ample headroom). Use guarded path for injection. 2. **TIA (summing node) main current summation & conversion** * Purpose: convert the tiny residual current (after coarse + fine cancellation) into voltage with large transimpedance. * Implementation: op amp configured as TIA with **R_F = 100 M** and small feedback capacitor (C_F) for stability. * Suggested TIA op amp: **LMP7704-SP** (ultra-low input bias ~fA, space-qualified). This is critical input bias must be 100 pA and stable. * Suggested C_F: **15 pF** (start ~2 pF) tune for stability with your detector capacitance. Guard the summing node with driven guard. * **Why 100 M?** 0.1 nA 100 M = **10 mV**. That gives comfortable voltage per detectable step while keeping resistor noise manageable (you can average to further improve SNR). 3. **Fine analog nulling servo (integrator + VI)** * Purpose: null the residual at the TIA summing node down to 100 pA automatically (no digital DAC). * Implementation: * Buffer the TIA output (very low-noise buffer), form an error voltage (Verr) that represents residual. * Feed Verr into a **slow integrator** (op amp integrator) whose output, after appropriate scaling/limiting, drives a **fine VI converter** that injects I_fine into the summing node. * The integrator drives until Verr 0 (null). Time constant should be long (seconds) so loop is stable and not noisy. * Suggested op amp (integrator/fine actuator): **OPA4277-SP** (precision, low drift, space variant) or similar. The VI ratio must be scaled so small integrator voltage changes correspond to pA-level correction. * Example scaling approach (practical): limit integrator swing to 1 V and choose R_fine so that 1 V 100 nA; then include a **1:1000 current divider** (passive or active current mirror) to get 100 pA per 1 mV effective integrator micro-step. But a simpler practical choice is: * Make the integrator output limited to 1 mV effective at the final VI resistor by adding a large divider or an attenuator before the VI. (Design detail below.) * **Concrete simple numeric option (recommended to prototype):** * Configure fine VI with R_fine = **10 M** and clamp integrator output to 1 mV (via precision voltage clamp / divider). Then 1 mV / 10 M = 100 pA exactly your detection threshold. * Implementation note: producing 1 mV swing from an op amp directly is delicate better to have integrator produce 1 V then use an attenuation of 1:1000 (precision resistor network) feeding the R_fine. This lets the integrator operate with comfortable voltages and lets the VI resistor see the tiny voltage. 4. **Buffer / subtractor / ADC driver** * Purpose: buffer TIA output for ADC, optionally remove tiny DC offset, filter, level-shift to ADC input range. * Suggested op amp: **ISL70227SRH** (low voltage noise, space-hardened) or similar for best low-noise buffering and subtraction. * Provide anti-alias filtering and a second-order low-pass to set measurement bandwidth (trade noise vs response time). 5. **ADC**, optional but recommended for record: use a high-resolution ADC (24-bit space-grade ADS family). ADC reads the post-buffered TIA output; sampling and averaging will improve detection confidence. # Recommended concrete numeric choices & target performance * **R_F (TIA)** = **100 M**. * Signal per 100 pA: **10 mV**. * Signal per 0.1 nA: **10 mV** (same). * **C_F (TIA)** = **2 pF** (tune). * **Coarse VI resistor** = **R_coarse = 2.49 k**, Vref 2.5 V coarse current range ~01 mA. Use 10-turn pot for tuning coarse injection. * **Fine VI resistor** = **R_fine = 10 M** (driven by an attenuated integrator output such that 1 mV corresponds to 100 pA). Implement integrator 1000 attenuation R_fine. * **Nulling integrator time constant**: choose integrator Rint and Cint for loop bandwidth << measurement bandwidth. Example: loop bandwidth ~0.01 Hz integrator time constant 10100 s (start conservative). * **Measurement bandwidth**: keep it narrow to reduce noise. Example: BW = 0.1 Hz or 1 Hz depending on how fast you need updates. Lower BW lower integrated noise. (SNR scales as 1/BW.) # Expected noise / SNR ballpark (practical) * For **R_F = 100 M**, earlier Johnson & op-amp example gave output noise density ~**1.29 V/Hz**. * For a single 10 mV signal (100 pA 100 M) integrated over **0.1 Hz BW (RMS noise 1.29 V 0.1 0.41 V)** SNR 10 mV / 0.00041 V **24,390** (very comfortable). * That means with appropriate averaging and narrow BW the 100 pA step is well above noise. (These are approximate; real op-amp datasheet numbers, resistor noise, and layout leakages must be used to refine.) # Key practical caveats / things that will make or break project * **Guarding/driven shields:** mandatory. Drive guard at summing node potential around traces and resistor island to eliminate surface leakage that can exceed pA. * **Resistor selection:** choose precision, low VCR and low noise high-value resistors (specialized 100 M types). Do not use cheap thick-film megohm resistors for the 100 M feedback. Consider buying space/precision high-value resistors or make guarded resistor dividers. * **Op amp input bias & leakage:** pick the TIA amp with fA input bias (LMP7704-SP recommended). Any bias/leakage comparable to 100 pA will ruin nulling. * **Grounding & layout:** single-point star ground, short traces at summing node, separate analog ground plane. Cleanliness (no flux residue) is critical. * **Integrator stability & offset:** integrator drift and offset must be limited; include offset-trim or occasional auto-reset to avoid integrator wind-up. Use a low bias integrator op amp with low input offset and low input bias drift (OPA4277-SP fits). * **Protection:** ensure the coarse driver can be limited so it cannot drive the summing node into destructive levels, and include transient suppression at input. * **Temperature drift & calibration:** even with nulling, long-term drift of resistor VCR/TCR and amplifier offsets can cause error implement periodic recalibration or reference checks if absolute accuracy matters. # Why this meets your requirement (100 pA resolution) * With R_F = 100 M, 100 pA 10 mV. 10 mV is comfortably measurable with a 24-bit ADC or even a lower-bit ADC with enough averaging. The nulling loop removes the 755 A baseline so the TIA node remains in linear range without needing impractically large or small passive elements. Analog integrator fine nulling can drive residual to below 100 pA if implemented with careful scaling and low-noise components. Guarding and resistor selection keep leakages below the pA target. # Final practical next steps (if you want to proceed) 1. ChatGPT said:

Nice lets unpack the whole analog-only architecture step-by-step and show the exact circuits, part roles, values and tuning procedure so you can prototype without guessing. Ill keep it practical: block explanation circuit topology for each block key component choices (the space parts you gave) equations, tuning steps and worst-case pitfalls.

Short recap of the topology

Coarse VI (manual) summing node (TIA) fine VI (integrator servo)
TIA (R_F = 100 M, C_F 2 pF) low-noise buffer/subtractor anti-alias LPF ADC (optional)

The coarse source removes the ~750 A baseline. The fine integrator injects tiny pA corrections until the TIA output nulls. The TIA converts residual current to voltage (10 mV per 100 pA).

1) Coarse analog VI (manual) circuit & parts

Purpose: subtract most of the baseline so the TIA never saturates and the fine loop only needs to correct pA.

Topology (simple and robust): op amp current-source (floating) that sources/sinks into the summing node. Use a precision reference + multi-turn pot to set the controlling voltage.

Circuit (textual):

  • Precision reference (VREF = +2.5 V) 10-turn pot (multi-turn, low tempco) Vpot.

  • Vpot fed to a voltage-to-current converter: classic op amp current source (op amp, Rset to ground, output drives summing node through output resistor). Example: op amp configured as a floating Howland or simpler transconductance stage:

    • Non-inverting input = Vpot.

    • Feedback resistor R1 between output and inverting input, R2 from inverting input to summing node.

    • Choose matched resistor ratios to make Iout Vpot / R_coarse (depending on chosen topology).

Recommended parts & values:

  • Driver op amp: OPA4H199-SEP (your suggested rad-hard coarse driver) chosen for drive capability and radiation tolerance. If not available, pick a precision low-drift op amp that can source ~1 mA.

  • R_coarse 2.49 k with Vpot up to ~2.49 V gives 1 mA full range (plenty).

  • Put a series current-limit (small resistor or clamp) to protect the summing node in case of faults.

Why this, not direct pot into summing node?

  • The summing node must be held at virtual ground by the TIA. Injecting current through a driver op amp keeps that node stable and prevents loading of the TIA.

2) TIA (summing node) circuit & parts

Purpose: convert residual detector current into voltage with very high transimpedance.

Topology: classic op amp TIA with feedback resistor R_F and feedback capacitor C_F in parallel for stability.

Circuit (textual):

  • Negative input = summing node. Detector current and both VI injections connect here.

  • Positive input = local analog ground (or mid-rail if single-supply).

  • Feedback: R_F = 100 M in parallel with C_F 2 pF.

Recommended parts & values:

  • TIA op amp: LMP7704-SP (ultra-low input bias, fA regime). If real part isn't available, find one with input bias 100 pA and low current noise.

  • R_F = 100 M (use precision, low VCR, low-leakage resistor vendor high-value resistor or guarded resistor island).

  • C_F = 2 pF (start here; tune as needed).

  • Input protection: small series resistor or fast clamp diodes outside the summing node (keep them out of the summing node path to avoid leakage).

Key equations:

  • Output voltage: Vout=IresidualRFV_{out} = - I_{residual} \cdot R_FVout=IresidualRF.

  • Sensitivity: 100 pA 1001012100106=10 mV100 \times 10^{-12} \times 100\times10^6 = 10\ \text{mV}1001012100106=10 mV.

  • TIA bandwidth (approx): f3dB12RFCtotf_{-3dB} \approx \dfrac{1}{2\pi R_F C_{tot}}f3dB2RFCtot1 where Ctot=CF+Cdetector+Camp,inpC_{tot} = C_F + C_{detector} + C_{amp,inp}Ctot=CF+Cdetector+Camp,inp. With R_F = 100 M and Ctot 10 pF, f 160 Hz; add C_F to reduce and stabilize to desired BW.

Stability & compensation:

  • Choose C_F to put a dominant pole in the feedback so the loop is stable given op amp open-loop gain and input capacitance.

  • If oscillation happens: increase C_F slightly (0.55 pF range) or add series resistor in the feedback path (rare with such high R).

3) Fine integrator nulling loop (analog servo) circuit & parts

Purpose: automatically null the residual current close to zero (within 100 pA) using an analog integrator that adjusts a fine VI source.

Overall control idea: TIA output (Vout) error amplifier / offset comparator slow integrator attenuator fine VI injection into summing node. When Vout desired reference (typically 0 V or mid-scale), integrator output stops (steady state).

Topology details & circuit:

  1. Error sense: Buffer of TIA output (very low noise buffer). Subtract desired setpoint if not ground.

    • e.g. Buffer: unity buffer op amp (low noise).

  2. Integrator: op amp integrator: Vin = buffered error, with Rint in series into the inverting input and Cint in feedback from output to inverting input. Non-inverting input = reference (0 V).

    • Choose Rint & Cint for very slow loop ( = RintCint). Example: Rint = 1 M, Cint = 10 F = 10 s (big cap recommended to be low-leakage, e.g. Tantalum/ceramic; think about bias).

  3. Limiting & scaling: Integrator output limited to 1 V (or 12 V supply depending) using precision clamp or back-to-back diodes + op amp rails to prevent wind-up.

  4. Attenuation: Integrator output precision attenuator (1:1000) so that 1 V from integrator becomes 1 mV to the fine VI stage.

  5. Fine VI stage: simple op amp transconductor or op amp with R_fine to convert the attenuated voltage to pA-level current into summing node.

    • Use: R_fine = 10 M. If attenuator outputs 1 mV, then 1 mV / 10 M = 100 pA.

Recommended op amps & parts:

  • Integrator/op amp: OPA4277-SP (low offset, low drift). Use this for integrator since integrator bias and drift directly affect nulling.

  • Fine VI resistor: R_fine = 10 M (precision).

  • Attenuator: precision resistor network with low tempco (1:1000 ratio using series/parallel matched resistors).

  • Buffer at TIA output: ISL70227SRH or similar low-noise buffer for the error sense path.

Why attenuate, not make integrator swing tiny?

  • Generating 1 mV cleanly from an op amp is fragile. Better to have integrator swing comfortable 1 V and attenuate with high precision resistors into the VI input.

Loop bandwidth & time constant:

  • Make loop very slow compared to measurement BW to avoid injecting integrator noise into measurement. Example: integrator loop fc 0.010.1 Hz ( = 10100 s).

4) Buffer / subtractor / ADC driver & anti-alias filter

Purpose: buffer the TIA output, optionally remove DC offset (if you want to log residual vs null point), and apply a low-pass filter before ADC.

Circuit:

  • Low-noise buffer (unity).

  • Optional differential subtractor to level-shift to ADC input range.

  • 2nd order antialiasing low-pass (active filter) set to your measurement BW (e.g. 0.1 Hz or 1 Hz).

Parts:

  • Buffer/subtractor: ISL70227SRH or any low-noise precision op amp.

  • ADC: 24-bit ADC (space grade ADS family if space requirement; on ground bench use ADS124S08/AD7768 equivalents). ADC sampling rates low; use digital averaging.

5) Protections, guarding, layout & resistor choices (critical)

Guarding / driven shield: Drive PCB guard/copper around the summing node and the high-value resistor island to the summing node potential. This removes leakage across PCB surfaces.

Resistors: Use high-value precision metal film or specialized high-value resistor technology (do not use general thick-film). For 100 M, commercial alternatives: guarded resistor mounts, Teflon-insulated leads, or purchase pre-made precision HV resistors.

Leakage control & cleanliness: Clean PCBs with IPA and bake if necessary. Flux and moisture cause pA-level leakage.

Cabling & connectors: Keep detectors (if external) in guarded coax with driven shield and minimize stray capacitance.

Thermal & drift: Mount precision resistors away from hot components. Use low TCR parts.

Exact wiring summary (how to connect everything)

  1. Detector current node TIA negative input (summing node).

  2. TIA op amp positive input system ground (or virtual mid-rail if single supply).

  3. Coarse VI op amp output inject into summing node through low impedance / matched resistor (driver configured to source required coarse current).

  4. Fine VI output inject into summing node via R_fine (10 M). The fine VI input receives the attenuated integrator output.

  5. TIA output buffer anti-alias LPF ADC.

  6. TIA output (buffered) error amplifier integrator clamp attenuator fine VI.

Component list (BOM highlights)

  • TIA op amp: LMP7704-SP (or equivalent ultra-low bias, low current noise).

  • Coarse op amp: OPA4H199-SEP (space grade driver) or precision op amp able to source ~1 mA.

  • Integrator op amp: OPA4277-SP (low offset, low drift).

  • Buffer op amp: ISL70227SRH (low noise).

  • R_F = 100 M precision guarded resistor.

  • C_F 2 pF NP0/C0G small feedback cap (tunable).

  • R_coarse 2.49 k pot (10-turn multi-turn).

  • R_fine = 10 M precision.

  • Attenuator resistors: matched network to give 1:1000 attenuation (e.g. 1 M / 1 k equivalents in precise config).

  • Power supply: low-noise linear rails; if single supply, plan level shifting.

Tuning & step-by-step commissioning procedure

  1. Build guarded breadboard / PCB: implement driven guard plane around summing node and resistor island before connecting detector.

  2. No detector first: connect precision current source or short to ground to confirm op amp rails and no oscillation.

  3. Set coarse VI: using Vpot, set coarse injection to cancel the bulk of the 750 A so TIA output is near mid-range but not saturated.

  4. Set TIA compensation: with coarse set, probe TIA output. Adjust C_F to remove ringing. If you see oscillation, increase C_F slightly.

  5. Close integrator loop slowly:

    • With integrator disabled, check integrator op amp rails and offsets.

    • Enable integrator but with very slow time constant (RintCint large). Confirm integrator reduces TIA output slowly toward zero.

    • Confirm integrator clamp limits work (no rail-to-rail saturation).

  6. Verify fine scaling: Check that 1 mV (after attenuation) into R_fine gives expected 100 pA by injecting known small current and observing TIA output change (10 mV per 100 pA).

  7. Measure noise:

    • With detector shorted/grounded and loop nulling, measure Vout noise across the chosen BW. Convert to equivalent pA noise by dividing by R_F.

  8. Connect detector and repeat nulling + measure step responses.

  9. Long term tests: warm up for hours and monitor integrator drift. If integrator winds up, increase clamp or add occasional manual reset.

Expected measurable numbers (practical)

  • Sensitivity: 100 pA 10 mV at TIA output.

  • Target measurement BW: 0.11 Hz (tradeoff between speed and noise).

  • Noise ballpark: with R_F=100 M and a low e_n amplifier, output noise density could be ~1 V/Hz (order of magnitude). Over 0.1 Hz rms 0.30.5 V equivalent current noise 35 fA rms (negligible vs 100 pA). Real world will be worse due to resistor noise & leakage expect tens of V at higher bandwidths; keep BW low.

  • Nulling accuracy: With careful layout/guarding, fine VI scaling and integrator clamp, you can null to <<100 pA. Real limit is leakages and bias currents of the TIA op amp.

Biggest make or break items (emphasized)

  1. Guarding/driven shields mandatory. Without driven guard the PCB leakage swamps pA signals.

  2. True low-bias TIA op amp input bias 100 pA. Any larger bias defeats nulling.

  3. Quality of 100 M resistor and its mounting (guarded) resistor noise & VCR matter.

  4. Integrator design and clamp integrator drift/wind-up must be controlled.

  5. Clean layout & assembly flux/contamination/moisture ruins pA circuits.

  6. Power supply cleanliness low noise regulators, local decoupling, star ground.

Quick answers to some likely follow-ups you might ask next

  • Compute a tighter noise budget from datasheet numbers I can do that if you give me the exact op amp part numbers you will use (I can use the ones above).

Quick reference single-line formulas

  • TIA output: Vout = I_residual R_F

Short answer: yes a coulombmeter / charge-integration approach can work for your requirement, and it trades off differently against the analog-nulling TIA you already have. Below Ill explain what a coulombmeter is, how it maps to your 100 pA target, the pros & cons vs the nulling TIA, key practical circuit choices (schematic-level), the math (step-by-step), and a recommendation for which to pick for your application.

What a coulombmeter (charge integrator) is conceptually

A coulombmeter measures charge (Q) accumulated on a capacitor over a known time interval T and computes current as I=Q/TI = Q/TI=Q/T. The front end is an integrator (charge amplifier): the input current charges an integration capacitor CintC_{int}Cint and the amplifier output VoutV_{out}Vout follows

Vout=1CintIin(t)dtIinTCintV_{out} = \frac{1}{C_{int}} \int I_{in}(t)\,dt \; \approx \; \frac{I_{in}\,T}{C_{int}}Vout=Cint1Iin(t)dtCintIinT

over an integration window TTT (until you reset the integrator). Thats why people call these coulombmeters or charge integrators you measure Q = IT as a voltage on a capacitor.

Basic arithmetic how 100 pA maps to a measurable voltage

(doing the arithmetic explicitly)

Let I=100 pA=1001012 AI = 100\ \text{pA} = 100 \times 10^{-12}\ \text{A}I=100 pA=1001012 A.

If you integrate for time T=1 sT = 1\ \text{s}T=1 s, the collected charge

Q=IT=1001012 C=1.001010 C=100 pC.Q = I \cdot T = 100\times 10^{-12}\ \text{C} = 1.00\times 10^{-10}\ \text{C} = 100\ \text{pC}.Q=IT=1001012 C=1.001010 C=100 pC.

Voltage on capacitor CintC_{int}Cint after time TTT:

V=QCint=ITCint.V = \frac{Q}{C_{int}} = \frac{I\cdot T}{C_{int}}.V=CintQ=CintIT.

Examples:

  • Cint=10 pF=101012 FC_{int} = 10\ \text{pF} = 10\times10^{-12}\ \text{F}Cint=10 pF=101012 F:

    V=1001012101012=10 V.V = \frac{100\times10^{-12}}{10\times10^{-12}} = 10\ \text{V}.V=1010121001012=10 V.

    (100 pA integrated 1 s on 10 pF 10 V. Large swing.)

  • Cint=1 nF=1109 FC_{int} = 1\ \text{nF} = 1\times10^{-9}\ \text{F}Cint=1 nF=1109 F:

    V=10010121109=0.1 V=100 mV.V = \frac{100\times10^{-12}}{1\times10^{-9}} = 0.1\ \text{V} = 100\ \text{mV}.V=11091001012=0.1 V=100 mV.

  • Cint=10 nFC_{int} = 10\ \text{nF}Cint=10 nF:

    V=10 mV.V = 10\ \text{mV}.V=10 mV.

So you can trade CintC_{int}Cint and TTT so that your expected 100 pA step produces a convenient voltage for your amplifier/ADC.

Pros / Cons: Charge integrator (coulombmeter) vs analog-nulling TIA

Charge integrator (coulombmeter) Pros

  • Very good low-frequency resolution by increasing integration time TTT (SNR improves with longer TTT).

  • Simpler front-end conceptually integrate then digitize; no continuous high-value feedback resistor required.

  • Can be extremely linear and easy to calibrate (Q = IT).

Charge integrator Cons / pitfalls

  • Bandwidth limited. To detect 100 pA with good SNR you may need long TTT (seconds minutes depending on noise).

  • Leakage & bias currents (op amp input bias, dielectric absorption, capacitor leakage, and PCB leakage) directly corrupt integrated charge. If leakage pA, long integration times become useless.

  • Reset/rollover handling: you must periodically reset the integrator (switch) and handle switching transients carefully (make/reset with low charge injection switches or mechanical relays).

  • Guarding & layout equally critical. Driven guard, guarded capacitor mount, and cleanliness are mandatory.

  • Integrator amplifier selection is critical need electrometer/op amp with fA-level input bias and extremely low input leakage.

Analog nulling TIA (your original architecture) Pros

  • Real-time current measurement, immediate response to steps; fine nulling loop keeps TIA in linear range.

  • Simultaneous measurement and nulling without periodic resets.

  • Easier to set measurement bandwidth and control noise via low-pass filtering.

  • Easier to implement continuous nulling to remove large baseline currents.

Analog nulling TIA Cons

  • Requires very high-value feedback resistor (100 M) and careful resistor selection.

  • Nulling servo complexity and need to implement VI injectors (you already designed this).

  • TIA resistor noise and amplifier noise are present, but with narrow BW this is manageable.

Practical considerations if you choose a coulombmeter (implementation notes)

  1. Integrator amplifier (electrometer op amp): choose an amplifier with input bias current 100 pA (preferably fA range) and extremely low input leakage and low 1/f noise. Examples commonly used in precision electrometers: LMP7721 family, AD549 family, or dedicated electrometer amplifiers (but check datasheets). You earlier suggested LMP7704-SP for TIA; for integrator you want similarly low-bias devices.

  2. Integration capacitor CintC_{int}Cint:

    • Must be low-leakage, stable dielectric (NP0/C0G for small pF; for nF you may need polypropylene film caps). Dielectric absorption is a concern for charge accuracy.

    • Mount in guarded island; minimize stray leakage.

  3. Integration time TTT:

    • Choose TTT by the required voltage swing and acceptable measurement rate.

    • Example: if you want 100 pA 100 mV, choose Cint=1 nFC_{int} = 1\ \text{nF}Cint=1 nF and T=1 sT = 1\ \text{s}T=1 s.

    • If you want faster detection (e.g., 0.1 s), either shrink CintC_{int}Cint or accept larger voltage swing.

  4. Reset switch:

    • Use a low-charge-injection reed relay or high-performance MOSFET/CMOS transmission gate designed for electrometer work.

    • Mechanical reed relays have near-zero charge injection but are slower and bulky.

    • Solid-state switches must be chosen for ultra-low charge injection (often requiring special MOSFET switches and guarding).

  5. Leakage & guarding:

    • The integrator node must be guarded with driven shield at the integrator potential.

    • PCB surface finish, conformal coating, and cleanliness are critical.

    • Any leakage current (op amp bias, switch leakage, resistor bleed) integrated over T will look like extra current.

  6. Auto-calibration / offset removal:

    • Include zero or zero-current calibration cycles (short input to guard and measure zero) to estimate leakage/bias and subtract.

    • Consider dual-integrator (dual-slope) schemes (measure sample and reference alternately) to cancel drift.

  7. Noise & SNR:

    • Integrating over T reduces wideband noise. For white noise, SNR improves as T\sqrt{T}T (for fixed bandwidth limit). But 1/f noise and leakage limit long-T gains.

    • Be aware amplifier 1/f noise may dominate at long T.

Two practical circuit approaches for a coulombmeter

A Continuous integrator with periodic reset (simple)

  • Input integrator op amp (U) with Cint in feedback.

  • Every T seconds, sample Vout, then reset integrator to zero using low-charge switch.

  • Compute I_est = Vout Cint / T.

  • Good when you can tolerate discrete sample updates.

Advantages: simple; good resolution if leakage small.

Disadvantages: noise from switch transients; dead time during reset.

B Dual-slope (charge-balance / sigma-delta style) coulombmeter (preferred for precision)

  • Phase 1: Integrate unknown current onto Cint for fixed time T1 (open-loop).

  • Phase 2: Apply a known reference current of opposite polarity and count time until integrator returns to zero (or integrate until a comparator trips).

  • The ratio of times or counts gives I_unknown / I_ref, canceling many drifts.

  • This is like a dual-slope ADC but for current highly accurate, rejects drift and offsets.

Advantages: very good drift rejection and offset cancellation; great accuracy without demanding tiny Cint stability.

Disadvantages: more complex control & timing; needs stable reference current (you have coarse/fine VI capability to produce a precise I_ref).

Numerical example making 100 pA comfortable on ADC using Coulombmeter

Goal: 100 pA step 100 mV output (nice for ADC)

Choose T=1 sT = 1\ \text{s}T=1 s. We need CintC_{int}Cint such that:

V=ITCintCint=ITV.V = \frac{I\cdot T}{C_{int}} \Rightarrow C_{int} = \frac{I\cdot T}{V}.V=CintITCint=VIT.

Plugging I=100e-12 A, T=1 s, V=0.1 V:

Cint=10010120.1=1109 F=1 nF.C_{int} = \frac{100\times10^{-12}}{0.1} = 1\times10^{-9}\ \text{F} = 1\ \text{nF}.Cint=0.11001012=1109 F=1 nF.

So: integrator cap = 1 nF, T=1 s gives 100 pA 100 mV.

If you want faster sampling T = 0.1 s with same 1 nF:

V=100e120.11e9=10 mV.V = \frac{100e-12 \cdot 0.1}{1e-9} = 10\ \text{mV}.V=1e9100e120.1=10 mV.

So either reduce C_int or accept smaller voltage.

Note: ensure Cint dielectric and op amp leakage allow meaningful integration for that T.

Which should you pick recommendation for your case (baseline ~750 A, need 100 pA steps)

  • If you need real-time detection of changes and want a continuous measurement with analog nulling already designed: keep the analog nulling TIA. It gives immediate response, and your 100 M / nulling design yields 10 mV per 100 pA excellent for ADCs and control loops.

  • If you can tolerate slow updates (seconds) and prefer to trade bandwidth for extremely simple arithmetic and potentially better noise averaging, a coulombmeter (charge integrator) is viable but only if you can ensure leakage and bias currents are well below your 100 pA target over the integration interval. For very long integration times, leakage & op-amp bias will dominate and ruin the measurement.

  • If you need the best of both: consider a hybrid strategy:

    • Use the nulling TIA with R_F = 100 M for continuous monitoring and fast detection.

    • When a long-term low-noise measurement is needed (e.g., to confirm a small offset), switch the front end into an integrator mode and accumulate charge for high-resolution averaging. This is more complex but offers flexibility.

Quick checklist if you want to prototype a coulombmeter now

  1. Choose integrator op amp with fA input bias and low 1/f noise.

  2. Select Cint so that expected 100 pA chosen T produces a convenient voltage (e.g., 100 mV1 V).

  3. Design/reset switch with ultra-low charge injection (reed relay or specialized analogue switch).

  4. Implement driven guard and guarded capacitor/resistor island.

  5. Measure and characterize leakage/bias by measuring Vout with input shorted for the target T; if leakage produces voltage comparable to your signal, rework design.

  6. Consider dual-slope scheme if you need drift rejection.

Let me break this down clearly what TI means, how it applies to your 100 pA measurement requirement, and what you can and cannot do with standard CMOS vs electrometer-grade op-amps.

What TI Actually Means in That Statement

TI is saying:

1. Standard CMOS op-amps have input bias current IB few pA to few hundred pA.

This includes most general-purpose CMOS devices OPA3xxx, TLV9xxx, LMVxx, etc.

This range (5 pA500 pA) is NOT good enough for precision measurements at or below ~100 pA input because:

  • The op-amp itself injects a current comparable to your signal.

  • That bias current will appear directly as a measurement error in a TIA or as leakage in an integrator.

So standard CMOS = too noisy for your 100 pA resolution.

2. Special high-performance op-amps (e.g., OPA928) achieve IB < 1 fA (10 A).

These are electrometer or ultra-low bias CMOS inputs with:

  • special FETs

  • special input isolation

  • special trimming

  • low leakage packaging

  • engineered to be 1000 to 1,000,000 better than normal CMOS

At 1 fA bias:

  • It is 1e-15 A

  • Your signal is 100e-12 A

  • Error is only 0.001% negligible.

This category of op-amps is compatible with your 100 pA requirement.

3. Why does TI say it requires additional circuitry and design?

Because achieving fA-level bias currents requires:

  • guarding

  • ultraclean PCB

  • no solder flux residues

  • low-leakage headers

  • low leakage switch

  • no FR4 contamination on the high-impedance node

  • low DA capacitors

  • environmental control (humidity)

  • special input stage design

In other words:

The op-amp alone cannot give you fA-level performance if your PCB leaks 100 more.

So what does that mean for your design?

You want:

  • resolution ~ 100 pA

  • baseline current huge (~750 A, but you null it)

  • you detect changes as small as 100 pA

In both the TIA and coulombmeter/integrator, the limiting factor becomes input bias current and PCB leakage.

Lets evaluate both:

TIA Case

Your TIA has:

  • RF = 100 M

  • gain = 10 mV / 100 pA excellent.

But what about op-amp input bias?

If you use standard CMOS op-amp IB 5 pA, that is:

5% error of your signal.

If IB 50 pA, that is 50% error unacceptable
If IB 300 pA, that is 3 your signal impossible

Therefore:

You MUST use an electrometer-grade op-amp (<1 fA to <50 fA).

These include:

  • OPA928

  • LMP7721

  • AD549

  • ADA4530-1 (gold standard for sub-pA TIA)

  • TI OPA129 family

Coulombmeter Case

In an integrator:

  • IB and PCB leakage integrate over time

  • so even 1 pA leakage 1 pC/s drift

For integration time T = 1 s:

  • your signal = 100 pA 100 pC

  • leakage = 1 pA 1 pC 1% error

  • leakage = 10 pA 10 pC 10% error

  • leakage = 100 pA 100 pC 100% error unusable

Therefore:

A coulombmeter absolutely requires fA-level leakage and bias performance.
Otherwise, drift dominates the signal.

So again: only electrometer-grade amplifiers are suitable.

  • You can connect photodiodes, ion sensors, gas sensors, etc.

  • The op-amp won't load your source

  • You wont introduce large measurement error

Your SG01XL-BC5 photodiode has dark currents of likely 10100 pA.
So a standard CMOS op-amp with 10 pA IB would double your dark current.

But OPA928 with 0.21 fA IB will cause 0.0002% error.

Below is the cleanest, clearest explanation of EXACTLY how a Coulomb meter works, specifically tailored to your ozone photodiode current measurement (100 pA resolution).

I will explain it in layers:

  1. Concept (one-line explanation)

  2. Core circuit diagram (ASCII)

  3. Step-by-step operation (very clear)

  4. Mathematical derivation

  5. What hardware is required

  6. Why it is extremely sensitive (and extremely tricky)

  7. Whether it is better than your TIA architecture

1. ONE-LINE EXPLANATION

A Coulomb meter converts current into charge by integrating it over time:
Q = I dt.
The op-amp integrator produces a voltage Vout that is directly proportional to the charge delivered by your photodiode.

2. CORE CIRCUIT (THE ACTUAL COULOMB METER)

scss
                Photodiode current (I)
                     
                
                  FET    
                  op-amp 
                
                       (inverting input = virtual ground)
                     
                 [ Summing node ]
                     
                     
                                     
                               
                                Integrator 
                                 Cf, Rf    
                               
                                     
                                 Vout(t)

The op-amp is configured as an integrator:

  • Feedback capacitor: C_f

  • Sometimes a reset switch across C_f

  • Sometimes a huge resistor R_f (to prevent drift)

3. STEP-BY-STEP: WHAT ACTUALLY HAPPENS

Step 1: Photodiode generates current I(t)

Your SG01XL-BC5 photodiode outputs a current proportional to UV intensity.
This current can be as small as 100 pA change you want to detect it.

Step 2: Op-amp holds summing node at virtual ground

The op-amp (electrometer grade) forces the inverting input to 0 V.
Therefore, all photodiode current MUST flow into the feedback capacitor Cf.

This is the key:

Step 3: The capacitor stores the charge

Current flowing into Cf deposits charge Q:

Q = C V

Step 4: The voltage at output ramps

Because the capacitor accumulates charge:

dV/dt = I(t) / C_f

So the output voltage is a ramp whose slope is proportional to your tiny current.

Example:

Let:

  • I = 100 pA

  • C_f = 1 nF

Then:

dV/dt = (100 10) / (1 10) = 0.1 V/s

Meaning:
A 100 pA change gives a 100 mV change in just 1 second.

This is extremely easy to measure with even a 12-bit ADC.

Step 5: Reset the capacitor periodically

A MOSFET or CMOS analog switch discharges Cf:

vbnet
RESET: short Cf  Vout = 0  new measurement cycle begins

4. MATHEMATICS (THE COULOMB METER EQUATION)

The output voltage is:

Vout(t) = - (1/Cf) I(t) dt

OR if current is constant:

Vout(t) = -(I/Cf) t

Therefore:

  • Slope tells you the current

  • Total ramp height tells you charge delivered

5. WHAT HARDWARE IS NEEDED

To make a coulomb meter with 100 pA sensitivity, you need:

ComponentRequirementWhy
Op-amp<1 fA biasIB ruins measurement
Cf0.110 nF, C0GLow dielectric absorption
Reset switchLow leakage <10 fAOtherwise drift
PCBGuard ring, cleanedFR4 leakage >100 pA in humid conditions
EnvironmentDry, cleanHumidity introduces pA leakages

Typical op-amps used:

  • ADA4530-1 (industry standard for coulombmeters)

  • OPA928 (TI)

  • LMP7721

  • AD549

6. WHY IT IS EXTREMELY SENSITIVE (and tricky)

Advantanges

Coulomb meter naturally amplifies pA signals into large voltage ramps.

E.g., I = 100 pA, Cf = 1 nF ramp = 0.1 V/s
Just 1 second 100 mV change trivial to measure.

Disadvantages

  1. Leakage currents cause false charge

  2. Op-amp input bias adds as error

  3. Dielectric absorption of Cf creates memory effects

  4. Integrator drift requires a reset

  5. Cannot measure absolute DC current without drift issues

  6. You lose real-time instantaneous current only get integrated value

7. Is Coulomb Meter Better Than Your TIA?

Coulomb meter benefits:

  • Higher sensitivity for pAfA currents

  • Natural averaging good SNR

  • Less ADC resolution needed

Coulomb meter drawbacks:

  • More drift

  • More leakage-sensitive

  • Harder to maintain stability

  • Harder to recover fast changes

  • You lose immediate DC value

  • Requires precise reset timing

TIA benefits:

  • Gives instantaneous current

  • Much more stable

  • Much easier to null 750 A baseline

  • Much easier to interface with ADC

  • No periodic reset continuous measurement

Thus for your design:

A TIA + analog nulling stage is the better architecture.

Coulombmeter is useful only if you NEED fA sensitivity and can afford resets.

8. Should YOU use a Coulomb Meter?

Given your system:

  • baseline = 750 A

  • detect changes = 100 pA

  • small dynamic target signal

A coulombmeter cannot handle the large baseline, even if you null it.

Your TIA architecture with:

  • coarse analog current cancellation

  • fine analog integrator servo

  • 100 M feedback resistor

is far more stable and practical.

B Which bandwidths matter (and why)

You actually have three different bandwidths to set and understand:

  1. TIA closed-loop electrical bandwidth (fast front-end)

    • Determined by R_F and total input/fb capacitance: fTIA12RFCtot f_{TIA} \approx \dfrac{1}{2\pi R_F C_{tot}}fTIA2RFCtot1.

    • Governs how fast the analog TIA itself can respond to step changes. Typical hundreds of Hz for R_F = 100 M and pF-level Ctot.

  2. Measurement / anti-alias bandwidth (what you report / care about)

    • The filtered bandwidth after the buffer/AA filter and before ADC. Controls the noise (RMS noise BW) and the effective time resolution of your measurement.

    • You choose this depending on how fast you need updates: 0.11 Hz is typical for pA-level stable measurements.

  3. Nulling integrator (servo) bandwidth

    • Very slow loop that adjusts the fine VI to keep the summing node near zero.

    • Must be much slower than the measurement BW (so it doesnt inject low-frequency noise into the measurement). Typical: 0.010.1 Hz (time constant = 10100 s).

C Concrete numeric calculations & examples

1) TIA bandwidth formula

fTIA12RFCtotf_{TIA} \approx \frac{1}{2\pi R_F C_{tot}}fTIA2RFCtot1

where Ctot=CF+Cdet+Camp,inC_{tot} = C_F + C_{det} + C_{amp,in}Ctot=CF+Cdet+Camp,in.

Using R_F = 100 M:

C_tot (pF)f_TIA (Hz) ( 1/(2RF C))approximate rise time tr 0.35/f (ms)
5 pF318 Hz1.1 ms
9 pF177 Hz2.0 ms
20 pF79.6 Hz4.4 ms

(These are single-pole approximations op-amp gain-bandwidth and extra poles can reduce the real bandwidth.)

Takeaway: with modest detector capacitance (single-digit pF) and C_F 2 pF your front-end will be naturally in the 100300 Hz range much faster than your measurement BW.

(earlier estimate for combined op-amp + resistor noise; use datasheet numbers to refine)

Measurement BWV_rms = eBWI_rms = V_rms / R_FI_rms in pA
0.1 Hz0.408 V4.0810 A0.0041 pA

Now compare to signal: 100 pA Vsignal = 100 pA 100 M = 10 mV.
So SNR (linear) = 10 mV / V_rms. Example:

  • BW = 1 Hz: SNR 10 mV / 1.29 V 7,750 huge.

  • BW = 0.1 Hz: SNR 24,540 even better.

Important: the above is idealized in real life resistor noise, leakage, packaging and 1/f noise increase these numbers. But you can safely see that with R_F = 100 M and narrow BW, 100 pA is easily measurable.

  • Make nulling loop measurement BW so it does not inject significant low-frequency control noise into the measurement path.

  • If measurement BW = 1 Hz, choose nulling loop corner 0.010.1 Hz (time constant 10100 s).

  • Practically: integrator Rint = 1 M, Cint = 10 F 10 s (fast end). Use = 10100 s and clamp integrator range.

E Practical tradeoffs & what changes bandwidth

  1. Detector capacitance (C_det): bigger C_det lower TIA BW. If you have long cable or large photodiode, expect tens of pF. Measure C_det and re-compute f_TIA.

  2. Feedback capacitance (C_F): increasing C_F reduces bandwidth but stabilizes the TIA. Tune C_F for critical damping of step response.

  3. Op amp open-loop gain & GBW: if op amp GBW is too low relative to R_F and Ctot, the achievable closed-loop TIA bandwidth will be lower than the simple formula; use op amp with adequate GBW margin.

  4. Anti-alias filter order & corner: steeper AA filter reduces out-of-band noise but adds group delay. For slow measurement (0.11 Hz), a 2nd order filter is ideal.

  5. Nulling speed: faster nulling reduces DC offset faster but may inject modulation/instability; keep it slow relative to measurement BW.

F Quick action checklist (what to measure / set next)

  1. Measure detector capacitance (C_det) with an LCR meter or from datasheet this changes f_TIA.

  2. Build TIA with R_F = 100 M and C_F 2 pF; probe step response and adjust C_F for damping.

  3. Choose measurement BW depending on required update rate: start with 0.1 Hz (best SNR) and later try 1 Hz if you need faster updates.

  4. Set nulling integrator 10100 s and verify it reduces Vout to near zero without oscillation.

  5. Implement a 2nd-order AA filter with fc = chosen BW and sample at 10fc in ADC, then average.

Example concrete numbers (final sanity check)

  • Suppose Ctot = 9 pF f_TIA 177 Hz (fast).

  • Choose measurement BW = 1 Hz Vrms 1.29 V, equivalent I_rms 0.013 pA (idealized).

  • A 100 pA step 10 mV output SNR 7,750 (plenty of margin).

  • produce the active anti-alias filter schematic for fc = 0.1 Hz and fc = 1 Hz.

ChatGPT said:

Nice Ill walk you through every block, one-by-one, in plain English so its easy to build, debug and tune. Ill keep each block focused: what it does, how its wired, the simple math, practical parts/values, what to look for, and short start-up/tuning steps. Think of this as the hands-on cheat-sheet for the analog-only nulling TIA system.

1 Overview (one sentence)

You have a detector current we subtract most of the big baseline with a coarse current source, the tiny leftover enters a TIA (transimpedance amplifier) that converts current voltage, a slow analog integrator injects tiny correction currents to null that leftover, and a buffer + anti-alias filter ADC records the result. Guarding, clean layout, and fA-capable op amps make or break everything.

2 Coarse VI driver (manual)

What it does (plain): takes your knob (pot) and continuously injects a large cancellation current into the TIA summing node so the TIA output doesnt saturate from the ~750 A baseline.

How its wired (simple):

  • A precise voltage reference (e.g. 2.5 V) multi-turn pot feeds a transconductor/op amp stage.

  • Op amp output goes to the TIA summing node (it sources or sinks current there).

  • The op amp senses summing node through a feedback resistor or Howland arrangement so it produces a stable current proportional to the pot.

Simple math:
If you set Vpot and use R_coarse 2.49 k, then coarse current Vpot / 2.49k. Example: Vpot = 2.49 V ~1 mA full range.

Suggested parts/values:

  • Op amp: driver capable of sourcing ~1 mA steady. (You suggested OPA4H199-SEP for rad-hard; any low-drift precision amp with required drive is fine.)

  • R_coarse 2.49 k + 10-turn pot for Vpot.

What to watch for:

  • Driver must be stable when driving the summing node (virtual ground). Avoid oscillation.

  • Add a small series resistor or current limit to protect the TIA node during mistakes.

  • Keep the coarse path physically separate from TIA high-value components (guard it).

Start-up / tuning:

  1. With detector disconnected, set Vpot = 0. Slowly increase to cancel the measured baseline so the TIA output moves near midrange without saturating.

  2. Do coarse adjustments only fine nulling will do pA corrections.

3 TIA (Transimpedance Amplifier) the heart

What it does (plain): converts the tiny residual current into a voltage: Vout = I_residual R_F. Its your actual sensor amplifier.

How its wired (simple):

  • Detector current and the two VI injectors (coarse + fine) join at the TIA negative input (the summing node).

  • Feedback from output to negative input is a very large resistor (R_F = 100 M) in parallel with a tiny capacitor C_F ( 15 pF).

  • Positive input of op amp to ground (or mid-rail if single supply).

Simple math:

  • 100 pA Vout = 100 pA 100 M = 10 mV.

  • Bandwidth approx: f 1/(2 R_F C_tot) where C_tot = C_F + C_det + C_amp_in.

Suggested parts/values:

  • Op amp: electrometer-grade (fA input bias): e.g. LMP7704-SP, OPA928, ADA4530-1, LMP7721 depending on availability.

  • R_F = 100 M (precision, guarded).

  • C_F 2 pF (start) tune to remove ringing.

What to watch for:

  • Input bias: must be 100 pA use fA-class op amp.

  • Leakage: PCB leakage or flux residues produce pA currents; use guarding.

  • Feedback resistor quality: cheap resistors are noisy and leaky. Use special high-value precision resistors or guarded resistor island.

  • Driven guard: surround node and resistor with guard copper driven to summing node potential.

Start-up / tuning:

  1. Build TIA alone. Short detector to ground. With coarse at zero, watch Vout: it should be near zero and stable.

  2. Inject a known small test current (e.g., by applying known voltage across known resistor into summing node) verify Vout = I R_F.

  3. Check transient response: apply a step current and observe Vout. If ringing, increase C_F slightly; if too slow, reduce C_F.

4 Guard / driven shield (non-sexy but critical)

What it does (plain): prevents tiny leakage currents on the PCB or connector insulation from stealing or adding pA to your measurements by keeping nearby surfaces at the same potential as the summing node.

How its wired (simple):

  • A guard amplifier (buffer) drives a copper ring around the summing node and the high-value resistor to the same voltage as the summing node.

  • Use guarded coax for detector cable: shield driven at summing node potential.

What to watch for:

  • Guard traces must be continuous and close to the node/resistor.

  • Any insulating gap, flux, or moisture defeats guarding.

  • Use short, guarded resistor mounting pins.

Start-up / tuning:

  • With guard disconnected, measure leakage then enable guard and verify leakage falls dramatically.

5 Fine analog integrator (null servo)

What it does (plain): slowly injects tiny pA currents into the summing node to drive the TIA output to zero (or desired setpoint). Its how you automatically null the large baseline to reveal tiny changes.

How its wired (simple):

  • TIA output low-noise buffer error amplifier/integrator (R_int into inverting input, C_int feedback).

  • Integrator output precise attenuator (e.g., 1:1000) fine VI stage (R_fine 10 M) injects current into summing node.

  • Integrator has clamps/limits to prevent runaway.

Simple math / scaling trick:

  • Integrator swing 1 V attenuate 1:1000 1 mV at VI input.

  • With R_fine = 10 M: I_fine = 1 mV / 10 M = 100 pA per 1 mV. So integrator micro-changes control pA-level corrections.

Suggested parts/values:

  • Integrator amp: low-drift precision (e.g. OPA4277-SP).

  • R_int/C_int choose = R_intC_int 10100 s (slow).

  • R_fine = 10 M; attenuator = 1:1000 (precision resistor network).

What to watch for:

  • Integrator drift & offset: use low offset op amp; clamp integrator output to avoid wind-up.

  • Avoid making integrator bandwidth close to measurement BW keep it much slower.

  • Attenuator must be precise and low-leakage (guard it).

Start-up / tuning:

  1. Leave integrator open; verify TIA output stable with coarse set.

  2. Enable integrator with long (e.g. 2060 s). Watch TIA output slowly drift toward zero.

  3. Reduce only if loop remains stable; if it oscillates, slow it down or add damping.

6 Buffer / subtractor and anti-alias filter (AA)

What it does (plain): take the TIA voltage, possibly remove any DC offset you dont want, and apply a low-pass filter before digital sampling so the ADC only sees the passband and not aliased noise.

How its wired (simple):

  • TIA out unity buffer (low-noise op amp) active 2nd-order low-pass ADC input.

  • If ADC needs level shifting, use a subtractor stage to shift DC to mid-scale.

Key choices:

  • Measurement BW (choose): 0.11 Hz typical.

    • 0.1 Hz gives lowest noise (best SNR) but slow updates (10 s time constant).

    • 1 Hz gives faster updates but higher noise.

  • Filter order: 2nd order Butterworth is a good starting point.

Suggested parts:

  • Buffer op amp: low-noise buffer (e.g. ISL70227SRH or similar).

  • Active filter: 2nd order Sallen-Key or multiple feedback design.

What to watch for:

  • Filter input loading can affect the TIA; always buffer first.

  • Match ADC input common-mode and range.

Start-up / tuning:

  1. Choose fc (e.g., 0.5 Hz). Build filter and measure response with a known sine/step.

  2. Sample ADC at >10 fc; implement averaging in firmware to reduce noise further.

7 ADC (optional)

What it does (plain): digitizes the buffered voltage for logging, closed-loop monitoring, or telemetry.

How to choose:

  • Resolution: 24-bit recommended for pA-level work because it provides excellent noise performance at low bandwidth.

  • Sampling rate: a few samples per second (based on measurement BW) then average.

Practical notes:

  • ADC input range should match expected Vout. With R_F = 100 M and worst residual maybe small mV range, you likely need 2.5 V or 5 V ADC input range.

  • Oversample and average to reduce noise.

Start-up / tuning:

  1. Connect ADC, take baseline readings with detector shorted and integrator closed. Check noise and offsets.

  2. If ADC shows saturations, re-check TIA scale and integrator clamps.

8 Protections / input protection

What it does (plain): prevent large currents or transients from damaging the TIA input or the detector.

Recommendations:

  • Series resistor (small, e.g., 10100 ) outside the summing node for catastrophic protection (must not be inside summing node).

  • Clamp diodes placed so they dont conduct during normal operation (i.e., outside the TIA node) protect external connectors.

  • Use current-limiting on coarse VI driver to prevent accidental huge injection.

  • ESD protection on connectors but keep them guarded and high-impedance from the summing node.

Watch for: any protection element placed at the summing node can add leakage or capacitance place protection carefully.

9 Layout, cleaning, and mechanical cautions (the reality)

Plain rules that matter more than math:

  • Short traces at summing node. Keep summing node area tiny.

  • Guard ring directly adjacent to summing node and resistor island; drive guard with buffer at node potential.

  • Use 2-layer or 4-layer PCB with continuous ground plane away from the guarded area (don't put copper under the guarded island unless driven).

  • Clean everything with isopropyl alcohol or special cleaning to remove flux residues.

  • Use conformal coat if humidity is a problem but validate it doesnt produce leakage.

  • Use guarded connectors and shielded cable (drive shield at summing node potential).

  • Mount high-value resistors on isolated posts or guarded islands.

10 Simple commissioning checklist (one page)

  1. Build TIA board with driven guard, but leave coarse and integrator disabled.

  2. Short detector to ground. Check Vout: should be near zero. If not, find offset/leakage.

  3. Add coarse VI and set so output not saturated (bring baseline down).

  4. Insert C_F tuning: step input and adjust C_F for no ringing.

  5. Enable integrator with long and confirm it nudges Vout toward zero.

  6. Inject calibrated small currents (resistor + small voltage) to verify Vout = I R_F (100 pA 10 mV).

  7. Connect buffer + AA filter + ADC, sample and measure noise. Choose fc and averaging to meet detection goals.

  8. Connect detector and repeat nulling + detection of known small step currents.

  9. Long-term test (hours): observe integrator wind-up, drift, and thermal behavior.

11 Quick troubleshooting (common failure modes)

  • Problem: You see huge random offsets or drift.
    Fix: Clean board, verify guard is driven, check for moisture or flux.

  • Problem: No response to tiny known currents.
    Fix: Check op amp input bias/health; verify R_F is correct and not shorted; verify summing node is at virtual ground.

  • Problem: TIA oscillates/rings.
    Fix: Increase C_F slightly; check op amp compensation and loop stability; shorten summing node traces.

  • Problem: Integrator winds up and never stabilizes.
    Fix: Add clamp limits, reduce integrator gain (increase ), check offset polarity.

12 Final plain summary (the practical big picture)

  • Use the coarse VI to remove the massive baseline so the TIA sees only the tiny residual.

  • The TIA (100 M) gives you 10 mV per 100 pA an easy voltage to measure.

  • Use a slow fine integrator that injects pA-level corrections via an attenuator + 10 M resistor to keep the summing node near zero this keeps the TIA linear and maximizes dynamic range.

  • Guarding, fA op amps, and high-quality 100 M resistor mounting are the non-negotiable keys to hitting true 100 pA performance.

  • Choose your measurement bandwidth (0.11 Hz) to trade speed vs noise; make integrator measurement BW.

FULL ELECTRONICS ARCHITECTURE EXPLAINED LIKE YOU WILL TELL TO YOUR GUIDE

Your detector produces a very large DC photocurrent (~750 A) plus a tiny change (~100 pA) when ozone absorbs UV.
The goal is to remove the big current and accurately measure the tiny current.

To do this, the electronics use a four-block architecture:

1. Coarse Current Cancellation Block (Big Offset Removal)

What it does:

This block injects a controlled current that cancels most of the detectors huge baseline current, so the next stage doesn't saturate.

Why we need it:

  • A TIA cannot handle 750 A directly with a 100 M resistor (it would output 75 V impossible).

  • So we remove ~749.9999 A, leaving only the small interesting current.

How it works:

  • A voltage-controlled current source (using an op-amp + pot + precision resistor).

  • The pot sets how much current we inject.

  • We adjust until the TIA sees only a tiny residual current.

Key point to tell guide:

This stage is like manually subtracting the large DC background so that the amplifier sees only the micro-changes caused by ozone.

2. TIA Transimpedance Amplifier (Main Sensor Amplifier)

What it does:

Converts the tiny remaining photocurrent into a measurable voltage.

Why we need it:

The detector outputs current, not voltage. The TIA converts:
Current Voltage, using a very large resistor.

How it works:

  • A very high input-impedance op-amp keeps the summing node at virtual ground.

  • A very large feedback resistor (100 M) produces high gain:

    • 100 pA 10 mV output

Why a huge resistor?

Because the tiny current changes must be translated into a voltage big enough for an ADC.

Key point to tell guide:

This is the main conversion stage. It converts pA-level currents into millivolt signals.

Special requirements:

  • Femtampere-level input bias op-amp (ADA4530-1 / OPA928 / LMP7721).

  • Guard rings to prevent leakage.

  • Clean PCB.

3. Fine Analog Integrator (Auto-Nulling Feedback Loop)

What it does:

Continuously trims the residual DC current so the TIA output stays centered.

Why we need it:

Temperature drift, photodiode drift, and radiation-induced shifts will keep changing the baseline.
We need auto-adjustment.

How it works:

  • TIA output goes into an integrator (very slow).

  • The integrator generates a tiny correcting voltage.

  • That voltage goes into a very high-value resistor (10 M) produces a tiny correction current.

  • This current is injected into the summing node to cancel slow drift.

What function it serves:

  • Stabilizes the TIA output

  • Removes long-term drift

  • Maintains measurement range

  • Acts like an automatic background subtraction

Key point to tell guide:

The slow integrator automatically balances the TIA by adding a very small correction current, so the TIA can always operate in its high-sensitivity zone.

4. Output Stage Buffer + Low-Pass Filter ADC

What it does:

Prepares the TIA output for digitization.

Blocks inside:

(a) Buffer

  • Provides current drive and isolates high-impedance TIA node from loading.

(b) Low-pass anti-alias filter

  • Removes high-frequency noise.

  • Bandwidth typically 0.11 Hz (your environment changes very slowly).

(c) ADC interface

  • Digitizes the clean, filtered voltage (suggest 24-bit ADC).

  • Firmware averages to further reduce noise.

Key point to tell guide:

This block cleans and digitizes the amplified photodiode signal so the onboard processor can compute ozone concentration.

Putting it all together (1-line summary)

We subtract the huge DC background using a coarse current source, amplify the tiny residual current using a high-value TIA, stabilize it with a slow integrator, and feed a filtered, buffered voltage to the ADC.

Bandwidth for Your Application

Your desired signal (100 pA ozone-related change) varies slowly, on the order of:

  • atmospheric changes: seconds to minutes

  • LED modulation: few Hz max

  • noise target: sub-millihertz

So the effective BW should be:

  • Low-pass filter cutoff = 0.11 Hz

  • Integrator time constant = 10100 seconds (slower than measurement bandwidth)

  • TIA bandwidth may be several kHz (but we limit it later)

This ensures:

  • minimal noise

  • stable output

  • no risk of oscillation

  • excellent pA detection resolution

The detector gives a huge DC current with tiny ozone-related variations.

Ahh, got it! Lets slow down and go step by step, really intuitively, without jumping into datasheets or fancy formulas. Ill explain the problem, why its a problem, and how the solution fixes it, block by block, so it actually makes sense in plain language.

Well assume the coarse VI already removed the big baseline, and the TIA gives a voltage proportional to the tiny leftover current. Now we look at what comes next.

1 The problem after TIA: tiny residual voltage is still noisy and unstable

Problem:
Even after cancelling the big baseline and converting the small current to voltage:

  • The TIA output is extremely sensitive any tiny drift in temperature, op-amp offset, or leakage currents can make the output slowly wander.

  • We want to detect 100 pA changes, but even a fA-level drift can slowly add up and mask the tiny signal.

Why its a problem:

  • You might measure a false change (drift) instead of the real ozone signal.

  • The TIA can stay linear only if the input current stays small; drift can push it outside the linear range.

2 Solution: Fine analog integrator (auto-nulling feedback)

What it does (simple):

  • This is like a tiny automatic current adjustment that slowly injects just enough current to bring the TIA output back to zero or near zero.

  • Its called nulling because it removes the residual DC, leaving only the tiny variations we care about.

How it makes life easier:

  • TIA stays in its sweet spot.

  • Long-term drift doesnt ruin measurements.

  • You can focus on the real signal (100 pA steps), not on slow changes caused by temperature, electronics, or leakage.

Analogy:

  • Imagine a boat floating in a river. The river slowly drifts (baseline). You want to measure tiny waves (signal). The fine integrator is like a tiny motor that slowly keeps the boat in place so the waves are easy to see.

3 Problem: TIA output is fragile and sensitive

Problem:

  • The TIA node is very high impedance.

  • If you connect it directly to anything else (ADC, cables, filters), the tiny currents can leak away.

  • The output can pick up noise from the environment.

4 Solution: Low-noise buffer + anti-alias filter

Buffer (why & how it helps):

  • A buffer is an op-amp stage that copies the TIA voltage without drawing any current from the TIA.

  • This protects the TIA from loading effects (anything that would disturb the delicate current-to-voltage conversion).

  • It lets you safely connect filters, cables, and the ADC.

Anti-alias filter (why & how it helps):

  • High-frequency noise exists in all electronics.

  • When we digitize the signal, any noise above half the sampling frequency can create fake signals in the measurement (aliasing).

  • A low-pass filter removes these unwanted high frequencies so the ADC sees only the slow signals we care about.

Life made easier:

  • TIA sees a stable environment.

  • ADC receives a clean, slow-varying voltage.

  • Noise and fake readings are minimized.

5 Problem: You want to digitize the signal for logging / processing

Problem:

  • Even after TIA, nulling, buffering, and filtering, the output is still analog voltage, not numbers.

  • To store data or compute ozone, you need digital values.

6 Solution: ADC (Analog-to-Digital Converter)

What it does (simple):

  • Converts the filtered, buffered voltage into a number your processor can read.

  • High resolution (24-bit) ensures 100 pA steps are distinguishable.

  • Oversampling + averaging further reduces noise.

Life made easier:

  • You can now store, process, and analyze ozone-related currents digitally.

  • Everything upstream is already optimized for accuracy and stability, so the ADC sees a clean signal.

Fine integrator (nulling)Drift in TIA due to offsets/leakageAutomatically cancels DC drift; keeps TIA in linear range

Big picture analogy:

  • Coarse VI: remove huge background river flow so you can see small waves.

  • TIA: measures the tiny wave height (current voltage).

  • Fine integrator: slowly nudges the boat to cancel slow drift in river flow.

  • Buffer + filter: keep the boat steady and remove random splashes (noise).

  • ADC: finally take a photo of the water level as numbers for analysis.

4 Radiation & space-grade requirements (must-haves / ask vendor)

When selecting parts for space, add these to your checklist and dont accept vague answers ask for data:

  • Total Ionizing Dose (TID): specify mission requirement (LEO, GEO, deep space) typical targets: 30 krad(Si) for many LEO missions; 100 krad(Si) for more aggressive missions. Use parts with guaranteed TID tolerance or get radiation test data.

  • Single-Event Effects: SEL (latch-up), SEU, SEFI. For analog parts, SEL immunity is critical. Ask for LET threshold or SEL test results.

  • Single-Event Transients (SET): op-amp outputs & inputs can spike under heavy ions ask for SET characterization; mitigation may be required for sensitive nodes (filtering, watchdog).

  • Displacement damage (if relevant): for optical detectors etc.

  • Screening / burn-in and lot traceability: vendor lot-level test reports, lot acceptance.

  • Space / military qualification: e.g., MIL-STD or ESA/QPL parts if mission requires.

  • Derating & redundancy guidance: vendor recommended derating factors for voltage/power and redundancy strategies.

Practical note: True space-grade fA electrometer op-amps are limited; you may need to select a COTS electrometer op-amp and run a radiation campaign to qualify it, or use shielding/operational mitigation (e.g., power cycling) and document risk.

5 PCB / assembly / environmental specs that affect op-amp choice

These arent op-amp specs but you must ensure compatibility:

  • Package cleanliness & surface finish: packages with exposed die/leadframes are sensitive; choose package types that minimize surface leakage paths.

  • Mounting & thermal path: op-amps with low leakage often require careful soldering profile to avoid damage.

  • Conformal coating: can help in humidity but may introduce leakage/dielectric absorption test coatings.

  • Temperature range: select op amp with guaranteed operation over mission range (e.g., 55C to +125C). For space, wide temp range is often required.

  • Vacuum operation: some parts outgas or have encapsulant issues check suitability for vacuum.

6 Test & qualification you must plan (practical steps)

  1. Electrical screening: measure IB, noise, offset vs temperature on parts from the lot pick best units for flight.

  2. Thermal cycling: at least 40 +85 C cycles (or mission-specific) and monitor IB & noise.

  3. Vacuum bake / outgassing tests if hardware goes into vacuum.

  4. Radiation testing: TID, SET/SEL tests on candidate op-amp types (or use vendor data).

    • If radiation results are unknown, plan a vendor/national lab test campaign.

  5. Long-term drift test: days/weeks to see integrator wind-up, IB drift.

  6. Vibration & shock: check for mechanical damage to packages that might change leakage.

  7. Assembly process control: specialized cleaning (no-clean residue removal), humidity control, ESD handling.

7 Practical examples (parts youve seen / candidates)

You already mentioned several in the conversation. Heres how they fit conceptually:

  • Electrometer / ultra-low IB (best for TIA/integrator):

    • ADA4530-1 (Analog Devices) commonly used electrometer front ends.

    • OPA928 (TI) TI claims sub-fA IB for some high-performance parts verify radiation readiness.

    • LMP7721 / LMP7704 (TI) low IB CMOS electrometer amps; check space variants (-SP) or qualification data.

    • AD549 family classic electrometer amps.

  • Integrator / buffer / filter (low noise, low drift):

    • OPA4277-SP (precision low-drift) good for integrator and control loops.

    • ISL70227SRH or other low-noise buffers for AA filtering and ADC drive.

  • Coarse driver: choose a robust precision op amp with good drive and space variant if available.

Important: Many of these parts are COTS; space use usually requires a radiation screening program or sourcing a space-grade variant (-SP in your notes). Always get vendor radiation test reports and ask about lot acceptance.

8 Practical selection priorities by block (short cheat list)

  • TIA: IB first, then input current noise, then C_in, then offset drift, then GBW; prefer electrometer class.

  • Integrator: IB & offset drift, then low 1/f noise, then output swing.

  • Buffer/AA: e_n, GBW (to implement filters), stability into capacitive loads.

  • Coarse driver: output current & stability, rail compliance, radiation tolerance.

9 PCB / system practices that make a worse op amp behave better

If you cant get the perfect op amp, these practices reduce the practical IB and leakage impact:

  • Driven guard on summing node and resistor island.

  • Short summing node traces, minimal surfaces exposed.

  • Bake & clean assembly to remove flux residues.

  • Conformal coat or hermetic sealing if humidity is a concern (test first).

  • Use guarded connectors and shielded cable for detector leads.

  • Temperature control or thermal stabilization if possible.

  • Local shielding to reduce single-event interactions in sensitive nodes (not a full radiation fix).

  • OPA4277 also a good buffer if you can handle the GBW and noise tradeoffs. Texas Instruments

4) Coarse VI driver (big current cancellation)

This stage must source/sink ~1 mA, be stable into the summing node and be robust (radiation-tolerant preferred).

Good candidates:

  • Space-qualified precision op-amps (e.g., vendor space variants of precision amps, or ISL70227 in applications where higher drive is acceptable). Look for output drive, stability and rad-hard pedigree. Renesas

B How to select op-amps for each block (a simple recipe)

Use this short checklist for selecting a candidate part for a block. For each op amp you consider, answer these must-pass questions (numbers are target ranges for your mission):

Mandatory checks (filter before deeper work)

  1. Input bias (IB) TIA: 10 fA, ideally 1 fA. Integrator: 1050 fA acceptable. Buffer/coarse: pA-range acceptable.

  2. Input current noise (i_n) lower is better. If you have i_n numbers, prefer <1 fA/Hz near DC for TIA.

  3. Voltage noise (e_n) for buffer and TIA keep e_n < ~10 nV/Hz if possible.

  4. Input capacitance (C_in) lower is better for bandwidth and stability, target < ~5 pF for best TIA BW.

  5. GBW & open-loop gain ensure GBW >> f_TIA so the amplifier behaves well. Aim GBW 10 f_TIA.

  6. Output drive / slew / capacitive load coarse driver needs current sourcing (12 mA), buffer must drive ADC and filter caps.

  7. Temp behavior check IB vs temperature and IB vs time (some parts have IB that explodes at high temp).

  8. Packaging & leakage risk choose packages with minimal leakage and suitable for guarding; metal/ceramic or exposed pad packages often better.

  9. Radiation & qualification for space: prefer vendor space variants (-SP), or be prepared to radiation-test. Ask vendor for TID/SET data.

  10. Supply rails ensure op amp supports your rail voltages (nulling integrator may need rails for 1 V swings, coarse driver may need rail headroom).

Practical ranking rule

  • If a part fails IB target for TIA, do not use it as the main TIA. It may still be OK for integrator or buffer.

C Recommended mapping: which op-amps to use for each block

Ill give Primary (best from your table or added ones) and Backup (if primary not available or cannot be qualified).

1) Main TIA (summing node, most critical)

  • Primary: ADA4530-1 or LTC6268 (if proven IB and noise in your lab); OPA928 is an excellent candidate from your list if ADA4530 isnt available.
    Why: ADA4530 is purpose-built electrometer front end and has integrated guard features; LTC6268 has extremely low e_n and low IB. OPA928 is a good modern low-IB candidate (20 fA guaranteed).

  • Backup: LMP7721 or AD549 (heritage JFET electrometer).
    Why backup: OK if you cannot get ADA4530/OPA928, but be very careful about temperature effects (LMP7721 IB increases with temp).

Selection notes: verify IB vs temperature and leakage in your PCB layout. If IB > ~10 fA in your setup, do not use as TIA.

2) Fine integrator (null servo)

  • Primary: OPA4277-SP (you already listed) or ADA4530-1 (if you want same electrometer quality on integrator).
    Why: OPA4277 has very low offset and drift, which matters for integrator wind-up; integrator does not require the absolute lowest IB, but drift/offset must be small.

  • Backup: OPA4277-EP (non-SP) or LMP7721 (if you want low IB integrator).

Selection notes: integrator should have low offset drift (V/C) and low 1/f noise. IB can be larger than TIA but keep it small.

3) Low-noise buffer / anti-alias filter driver

  • Primary: ISL70227SRH (rad-hard option you have) or LTC6268 (if not used in TIA).
    Why: buffer must have low voltage noise and be space-tolerant; ISL70227SRH is a solid, precision choice for space.

  • Backup: OPA4277 or general low-noise precision op amp with sufficient GBW.

Selection notes: buffer needs GBW filter fc, and must be stable into capacitive loads (or use series resistor).

4) Coarse VI driver (big current cancellation)

  • Primary: OPA4277-SP or a space-qualified precision op amp that can source 12 mA and withstand transients. If radiation hardening is essential, choose a vendor space-grade driver.
    Why: coarse driver needs robustness and stable output; IB not critical.

  • Backup: any robust precision op amp with sufficient output drive and space variant (LM124-SP is heavy; verify performance).

Selection notes: this stage should have output current limit and survive fault injection.

5) Guard driver (driven shield)

  • Primary: small unity-gain stable buffer (ISL70227SRH or same buffer used above). Must be low offset and able to drive guard capacitance at kHz speeds.

  • Backup: any unity-gain stable precision amp.

D Tests to perform on candidate op-amps (exact bench steps)

Before committing to a candidate for flight, run these tests on a representative PCB with your guarded layout (no detector connected yet):

Electrical / functional tests

  1. Input bias (IB) measurement at multiple temperatures (e.g., 20C, 25C, +60C, +85C). Measure IB by connecting TIA feedback resistor + short or using a dedicated electrometer test rig. Record typical and worst values.
    Pass: IB 10 fA at worst-case temp (for TIA).

  2. Input current noise (i_n) & voltage noise (e_n) vs frequency. Measure output noise density, then convert to equivalent input current noise using R_F (100 M). Compare to datasheet.
    Pass: noise low enough such that 100 pA SNR >> 10 in target BW.

  3. Open-loop and closed-loop stability check: build TIA with R_F = 100 M and C_F = 2 pF; step test and check ringing. Tune C_F as needed.

  4. Offset & offset drift: measure input offset and thermal drift (V/C) with the device mounted and in real thermal path.

  5. Input capacitance measurement (C_in) use LCR meter or infer from bandwidth.

  6. Long-term drift / integration test: close integrator and watch output for hours to see wind-up or bias accumulation. This reveals hidden leakage or bias instability.

  7. Capacitive load / output drive: ensure buffer and coarse driver drive expected loads and do not oscillate.

  8. ESD immunity / failure mode: intentionally create ESD scenarios compatible with assembly and ground handling to see what happens does IB badly change after ESD?

Radiation / environmental tests (flight prep)

  1. TID test (if vendor data not available) up to your mission dose measure IB/noise before and after.

  2. SEL / SET testing for single-event latch or transient (if candidate not space-qualified).

  3. Vibration & thermal vacuum tests of assembled PCB. Re-measure IB & noise after mechanical stress.

E Final short recommendations (practical set for prototype & path to flight)

  • Prototype lab build: TIA = ADA4530-1 or OPA928; Integrator = OPA4277; Buffer/AA = ISL70227SRH or LTC6268 (if spare); Coarse driver = OPA4277.

  • If you must pick only from your table now: TIA OPA928 or LTC6268 (LTC6268 has awesome e_n and low IB), Integrator OPA4277-SP, Buffer ISL70227SRH, Coarse OPA4277-SP.

  • Qualification: plan a radiation test program for the TIA amp (ADA4530/OPA928/LTC6268) or select a space-grade equivalent and re-run the bench IB/noise tests after radiation exposures.

F Quick selection checklist you can hand to your guide (one-page)

  1. TIA op amp must show IB 10 fA at worst-case temp in real PCB with driven guard.

  2. TIA noise must produce V_rms << 10 mV (the 100 pA signal) over chosen BW (0.11 Hz).

  3. Integrator must have offset drift <1 V/C and IB < 10-50 fA.

  4. Buffer must be low e_n (<10 nV/Hz) and stable into filter/ADC.

  5. Coarse driver must source 1 mA, include current limit, and be robust for transients.

  6. All flight candidates must be radiation-screened (TID & SET/SEL) or justified with shielding/mitigation.

Why these choices (short, simple reasons)

LTC6268 for the TIA why

  • Problem it must solve: the TIA sits at the summing node and any input bias or input capacitance directly kills sensitivity and bandwidth.

  • Why LTC6268 fixes it: extremely low input bias (3 fA) and tiny input capacitance (0.45 pF) gives highest SNR and widest clean TIA bandwidth with R_F = 100 M. Low voltage noise helps too.

  • Why not others: parts like ADA4350 / MAX74821 / ISL70227 have far higher IB or input noise; LMP7704-SP (200 fA) or ADA4350 (~0.1 pA) are orders of magnitude worse for the summing node. OPA928 (20 fA) is good but worse IB than LTC6268.

Practical caution: LTC6268 supply rails are limited (check your rails or use single-supply architecture); LTC6268 is COTS plan radiation testing or shielding for flight.

OPA4277-SP for integrator & coarse driver why

  • Problem it must solve: the integrator must be low-drift, stable over long time constants (10100 s), and have low offset so the null loop doesnt wind up. Coarse driver must be robust and drive ~1 mA.

  • Why OPA4277-SP fixes it: excellent low offset and very low drift, space variant available (-SP) makes it easier to qualify for flight. Good output drive and stability for driving attenuator/VI stages.

  • Why not other amps: LTC6268 is great for TIA but its limited supply and design make it less ideal for a long-term integrator or as a robust coarse driver. LMP7704-SP could be a backup but OPA4277 has better offset/drift for integrator work.

ISL70227SRH for buffer / AA and guard why

  • Problem it must solve: buffer must preserve low noise, drive filters and ADC, and be robust to radiation and spacecraft environments. Guard driver must track summing node cleanly.

  • Why ISL70227SRH fixes it: low e_n, wide supply range, and SRH (radiation-hardened / space-capable) variant ideal for post-TIA stages and for guard driving where space reliability matters.

  • Why not others: OPA4277-SP can be used but ISL70227SRH gives more space pedigree for the buffer role.
