What this means and how we fix it

What we lose if we stick with LTC6268 as-is:

  • No guarantee of tolerance to total ionizing dose (TID), single-event effects (SEE), or latch-up under cosmic rays / heavy ions.

  • Risk that radiation or space environment permanently damages or degrades the amplifier (bias current rises, leakage increases, noise worsens).

  • On a real mission, using a COTS op-amp without radiation screening can fail mission requirements and is usually unacceptable.

What we must do instead (for real space usage):

  1. Radiation qualification / testing run TID (e.g. up to mission dose), Single-Event Latchup (SEL), Single-Event Upset/Transient (SEU/SET) tests on LTC6268 (or any candidate) before approving it.

  2. Consider using space-qualified / rad-hard op-amps if available, use parts explicitly rated for space. If none meet the ultra-low-bias requirement, consider building a custom ASIC, or use shielding + redundancy + periodic calibration + error-checking to mitigate risk.

  3. Redundancy / monitoring / fail-safe design design system so a failure in op-amp (or drift due to radiation) can be detected and corrected (reset, re-zero, fallback amplifier, redundancy).

  4. Extensive ground characterization stress test over temperature, humidity, radiation simulation, and long-term drift in vacuum, etc.

What we know about LTC6268 (good for lab use, not for flight as-is)

From datasheet:

  • IB (input bias) ~ 3 fA typ at room temp. analog.com

  • Input capacitance 0.45 pF, low noise, high GBW. analog.com+1

  • Specified over 40 C to +125 C. analog.com+1

Missing: no mention of radiation tolerance, no SEL thresholds, no screening history.

Because of that, LTC6268 is great for lab experiments, ground prototypes, but not a guaranteed space-flight part.

What Id do if I were you and aiming for real space readiness

  1. Keep LTC6268 (or OPA928 etc.) for ground testing & prototyping. Use them to validate your architecture, noise performance, nulling scheme, guarding, layout, etc.

  2. Simultaneously search for a rad-hard / space-qualified low-bias amplifier this may not exist as a commercial ready-made part. Could be a custom ASIC, or you accept larger baseline + more aggressive nulling + shielding.

  3. Design flexibility: structure your circuit so you can swap the TIA amplifier easily (through socket, modular front-end) so if the qualified amplifier arrives later you can retrofit without redesigning everything.

  4. Plan for radiation tests and qualification campaign procurement of flight units, radiation exposure, post-irradiation test (bias current, noise, offset, stability), and acceptance criteria.

Short answer: Yes this design can work for detecting 100 pA steps on top of a ~750 A baseline provided you implement the critical layout, component, and verification steps I list below. You will not be guaranteed success if you skip guarding, proper op-amp selection, qualification, or verification on the real guarded PCB. Ill be blunt: the architecture is sound; the success probability is high only if you follow the mitigation & test plan.

Below I give a clear checklist: what must be true for success, what will make you fail, how to test and measure acceptance criteria, and fallback/contingency moves if something goes wrong.

1 Why the architecture is fundamentally sound

  • Coarse VI removes the huge DC so your TIA stays in range.

  • A 100 M TIA gives 10 mV per 100 pA comfortable signal level for ADCs.

  • Analog fine nulling keeps the TIA in its linear zone continuously so you see only the tiny deltas.

  • Using space-variant op amps (LMP7704-SP for TIA, OPA4277-SP for integrator/driver, ISL70227SRH for buffer/guard) trades off raw lab-best COTS performance for radiation pedigree while keeping low IB/noise in the femtopico regime.
    So the concept is right.

2 The single biggest truth: layout & leakage beat parts

No matter which op amp you choose, poor layout, contamination, or no guard will kill pA/fA measurements. If you get layout/guard right, the chosen parts will almost certainly allow detection of 100 pA steps. If you fail on layout/guard, youll likely fail even with the best electrometer amp.

Must-do items (non-negotiable):

  • Driven guard ring around the summing node and resistor island (driven to summing-node potential).

  • Short summing node traces, minimal exposed copper.

  • Use guarded coax for detector feed with driven shield.

  • Clean, flux-free, baked PCBs; test for surface leakage.

  • Use precision high-value resistors mounted on guarded island.

  • Use low-leakage plastics/insulators for standoffs.

  • Design so you can swap the TIA op amp easily (modular front-end).

3 Critical failure modes & how to detect them fast

  1. High leakage / surface currents

    • Symptom: TIA offset huge or drifting, integrator saturates quickly.

    • Test: short detector, disable coarse/fine injectors, measure Vout drift and IB on guarded PCB.

    • Fix: improve cleaning, guard, conformal coat or redesign island.

  2. Op-amp input bias too high in-circuit

    • Symptom: measured IB >> spec, noise bad.

    • Test: measure IB vs temp on PCB (with guard driven).

    • Fix: try alternative flight-grade op amp, re-evaluate guarding, or accept slower BW.

  3. Null integrator oscillation or too noisy

    • Symptom: low-frequency instability in measurement band.

    • Test: close loop, measure FFT/time-domain of Vout.

    • Fix: slow the integrator (increase ), clamp integrator limits, add damping.

  4. Unstable TIA (ringing/oscillations)

    • Symptom: ringing on step response.

    • Test: inject step/current pulse and measure Vout.

    • Fix: increase C_F slightly, verify op amp compensation, shorten summing node traces.

  5. Radiation-induced degradation

    • Symptom: IB rises after TID, odd transients (SET), or latch-up.

    • Test: TID and SET/SEL radiation tests on candidate flight parts.

    • Fix: choose better rad-hard part, shielding, redundancy, or periodic recal.

4 Runbook exact bench tests & pass criteria (do these now)

Do each of these on the actual guarded PCB with intended power rails and driven guard enabled.

  1. Summing node leakage & IB

    • Method: short input to guard; power up; measure current into summing node or measure Vout with known R_F (or use electrometer).

    • Pass: IB 10 fA ideal; 100 fA acceptable if you plan BW 0.1 Hz and accounting for resistor noise. If IB > 1 pA fail.

  2. Gain / sensitivity check

    • Method: inject calibrated small currents (e.g., 100 pA via precise resistor + source). Measure Vout.

    • Pass: 100 pA 10 mV 10% (R_F = 100 M). If not, check R_F & wiring.

  3. Noise budget

    • Method: measure output noise density; compute I_rms = V_rms / R_F over chosen BW.

    • Pass: I_rms << 100 pA (target 10 pA RMS ideally; better at 0.11 Hz). If noise comparable to signal, reduce BW or improve shielding/resistor.

  4. TIA step/stability

    • Method: step injection, observe Vout for ringing.

    • Pass: clean step, no sustained oscillation, controllable settling with chosen C_F.

  5. Null loop behavior

    • Method: enable integrator (set 10100 s); observe time to null and stability.

    • Pass: nulling reduces DC within timeframe, no oscillation, integrator clamps not hit frequently.

  6. Long-term drift

    • Method: log Vout for 2472 hours with integrator closed and detector shorted.

    • Pass: drift manageable (e.g., few mV over hours depending on spec) and integrator clamps not repeatedly tripped.

  7. Radiation screening (pre-flight)

    • Run TID to mission dose on a few samples; measure IB/noise pre/post. Test for SET/SEL.

    • Pass: IB/noise degrade within acceptable margin; no destructive latchup; transient rates acceptable or mitigated.

If you pass 16 on the guarded PCB, the system is very likely to detect 100 pA steps reliably on orbit (radiation caveats aside).

5 Acceptance thresholds to read to your guide (one-liners)

  • IB on guarded PCB 100 fA (best target 10 fA).

  • 100 pA injection Vout 10 mV (R_F = 100 M).

  • Equivalent input noise (BW=1 Hz) << 100 pA RMS (ideally 10 pA RMS).

  • Nulling loop can hold residual within 100 pA for hours/days after calibration.

  • Radiation testing: no catastrophic change in IB/noise up to mission TID (or plan with shielding/mitigation).

6 Practical contingency plan if something fails in testing

  • If IB too large: improve guard and cleaning re-measure. If still too high, switch to a different flight-grade amp with lower IB (LMP7704-SP family was chosen; find alternate space amplifier or accept longer integration/BW reduction).

  • If noise too high: lower measurement BW (0.1 Hz), increase averaging, or use slightly larger R_F (trade bandwidth & resistor noise).

  • If radiation causes unacceptable drift: test shielding (mm of Al), or use redundancy (dual front-end) and flight calibration cycles.

  • If TIA op-amp not space-qualifiable and COTS performs far better in lab: keep COTS for prototype & qualify via vendor radiation testing or request custom rad-hard part.

  1. Proceed with prototype using the flight set (LMP7704-SP TIA, OPA4277-SP integrator/driver, ISL70227SRH buffer), but also build a parallel lab prototype using the best COTS electrometer amp (e.g., LTC6268 or ADA4530) for noise floor/architecture validation. That lets you validate architecture and then map COTS vs flight device differences on the same guarded layout.

  3. Plan and fund radiation screening (TID + SET) for whichever flight candidate you choose its mandatory for space flight.

Use this exactly as-is in your report, or I can format as a PDF/slide if you want.

1 What we need and why (short list)

Goal: detect changes in photodiode current of 100 pA on top of a large baseline (~750 A) in a space instrument.

What we need and why:

  • High-sensitivity current-to-voltage stage (TIA) converts tiny residual current into a measurable voltage. Required because the detector outputs current, not voltage.

  • Coarse baseline cancellation (VI driver) remove the ~750 A DC baseline so the TIA can operate in its linear range and not saturate. Without this, the required feedback resistor would be impractical or the amplifier would rail.

  • Fine analog nulling (integrator + VI) automatically keep residual current near zero so the TIA sees only small deltas; this reduces dynamic range and improves linearity/stability.

  • Driven guard / shield & guarded resistor island prevent surface leakage and stray currents that easily swamp pA signals.

  • Low-noise buffer + anti-alias filter and ADC buffer the TIA output for digitization, remove out-of-band noise, and feed a high-resolution ADC for logging.

  • Space-grade / radiation-tolerant components and qualification plan because the mission is space, parts must be flight-capable or qualified (TID/SET/SEL tests).

  • Verification & test plan (bench + radiation) to demonstrate IB, noise, null stability, and post-radiation behavior on the actual guarded PCB.

2 All methods (how we will measure/achieve it)

These are the methods / implementation steps we will follow.

A. Architecture & design method

  • Use coarse VI to subtract the big baseline.

  • Use a high-R feedback TIA (R_F 100 M) to convert residual current to voltage.

  • Use a slow fine integrator that drives a fine VI injection (pA resolution) to null the TIA output.

  • Buffer + AA filter + ADC for digitization.

B. Layout & hardware methods

  • Implement driven guard around summing node and R_F island; guard cable shields.

  • Use precision, low-leakage high-value resistors for R_F and R_fine.

  • Keep summing node traces as short as possible; minimize stray areas.

C. Component selection method

  • Choose an electrometer-grade op amp for TIA (flight-capable or test-qualified alternative).

  • Use low-drift precision op amp for integrator.

  • Use rad-hard/space variants for buffer/driver where possible.

D. Bench verification & test method

  • Measure input bias (IB) on the guarded PCB across temperature.

  • Inject calibrated currents (100 pA steps) and confirm 100 pA 10 mV (with R_F = 100 M).

  • Measure output noise density and compute equivalent input noise for chosen BW (0.11 Hz).

  • Tune C_F for stability (step response) and choose integrator (10100 s).

  • Long-term drift test and integrator behavior.

  • Radiation tests: TID, SEL/SET for flight candidate parts; re-measure IB/noise post-irradiation.

E. Operational/testing methods in flight

  • Implement periodic calibrations/zeros (if needed) and diagnostic test currents.

  • Telemetry to monitor integrator output, TIA output and health (detect sudden changes suggesting radiation effects).

3 Why a TIA? (intuition + practical)

Simple intuition: A photodiode produces current; to measure it precisely you must turn that current into a voltage that you can sense and digitize. A TIA does exactly that: it forces the photodiode node to virtual ground and produces Vout = I R_F. For very small I, choose a very large R_F to get a useful voltage.

Practical reasons:

  • Direct digitization of tiny currents is impossible without conversion to voltage at sufficient amplitude.

  • TIAs give excellent linearity and fast response (set by R_F and total capacitance).

  • With proper op amp selection and guarding, TIAs can measure pA fA currents.

Key TIA trade: R_F must be high for sensitivity (100 M 10 mV per 100 pA) but high R increases resistor Johnson noise and reduces bandwidth. We manage that with narrow measurement BW and low-noise components.

4 The two TIA approaches (exactly what they are)

Approach A Direct TIA (single-stage high-R feedback)

  • How: Put the detector current into the negative input of an electrometer op amp with a single large feedback resistor R_F (e.g., 100 M) and small C_F for stability. Vout = IR_F.

  • Pros: Conceptually simple, continuous measurement, fast response (limited by C_tot and op amp GBW), single-stage electronics.

  • Cons: The TIA sees the full baseline current (750 A) unless you scale R_F extremely small (which ruins sensitivity), so practically this approach needs either impossibly large dynamic range in amplifier output or some way to remove the baseline elsewhere. Also high R_F must be physically high-value precision resistor (expensive, leaky concerns), and you must handle input bias current & leakage carefully.

Approach B Analog-nulling TIA (coarse VI + TIA + fine analog nulling)

  • How (block flow):

    1. Coarse VI injects a large cancellation current set by a pot / precision Vref into the summing node to remove most of the 750 A.

    2. TIA with R_F = 100 M converts the small residual current to voltage (10 mV per 100 pA).

    3. Fine integrator (very slow) senses TIA output and drives a fine VI (via an attenuator + R_fine, e.g. 10 M) that injects pA-level corrections into the summing node until the TIA output is nulled.

    4. Buffer + AA + ADC digitize the output for logging.

  • Pros: Keeps TIA in linear range without huge output swings; continuous nulling removes drift and baseline; enables very high sensitivity using moderate R_F.

  • Cons: More complex (two VI stages and an integrator loop); integrator must be slow and stable; needs careful attenuator and R_fine design; requires guarding.

5 Why the analog-nulling TIA approach is better for our case

Short: because of the huge baseline (~750 A) and small target delta (100 pA).

Detailed reasons:

  • Avoids impractical amplifier output: A straight TIA with R_F large enough to give 10 mV/100 pA would output 75 V for 750 A impossible. Nulling removes that baseline so the TIA output range remains small and within supply rails.

  • Maintains sensitivity and dynamic range: Coarse cancellation takes out most of the DC; fine nulling keeps the residual within 100 pA so the 100 M resistor works perfectly to give measurable voltage steps.

  • Continuous, automatic operation: The analog servo continuously corrects slow drifts (thermal, component aging, detector dark current), so you dont need frequent manual recalibration.

  • Noise & measurement control: Because the residual is small, the TIA can be designed with narrow measurement BW (0.11 Hz), giving excellent SNR. Resistor Johnson noise and op amp voltage/current noise are managed in a narrow BW.

  • Practical in space: The approach allows using space-qualified op amps with realistic rails and reduces the need for unreasonably large or exotic components that might not be space-producible.

6 Detailed explanation (circuit + components + tuning + tests)

Ill break this down into: circuit overview, components & values, step-by-step tuning/commissioning, expected numbers, pitfalls and test checklist.

6.1 Circuit overview (textual schematic)

rust
Vref -> 10-turn pot -> Coarse V->I driver -> Summing node ( input of TIA)
Detector current -> Summing node
Fine V->I (driven by integrator via attenuator -> R_fine) -> Summing node
TIA op amp:  input = summing node, + input = system ground; feedback R_F || C_F
TIA output -> Buffer -> AA filter -> ADC
TIA output -> buffer -> error amplifier -> slow integrator -> attenuator -> fine V->I driver -> Summing node
Guard amplifier -> drive PCB guard around summing node and resistor island

6.2 Key component choices & concrete numeric values (prototype)

  • R_F (TIA) = 100 M (sensitivity: 100 pA 10 mV)

  • C_F (TIA) = 15 pF (start 2 pF; tune for stability with C_tot)

  • Coarse VI resistor = 2.49 k with 10-turn pot (Vref = 2.5 V up to ~1 mA)

  • Fine VI resistor R_fine = 10 M (1 mV on this 100 pA)

  • Attenuator = 1:1000 (integrator 1 V -> 1 mV into R_fine)

  • Integrator time constant = 10100 s (loop BW ~0.010.1 Hz)

  • Measurement BW (AA filter) = 0.11 Hz (choice trades speed vs noise)

  • TIA op amp = flight-grade electrometer amp (e.g., LMP7704-SP or another space-qualified low-IB amp) (lab prototype may use LTC6268/ADA4530 but not for flight unless tested)

  • Integrator op amp = OPA4277-SP (low drift)

  • Buffer / guard driver = ISL70227SRH or other rad-hard precision amp

  • Summing node guard = guard amplifier drive copper trace surrounding summing node & resistor island

6.3 Key equations

  • TIA output: Vout = I_residual R_F

  • Fine injection current: I_fine = V_att / R_fine (V_att is attenuated integrator output)

  • TIA approx bandwidth: f_TIA 1/(2 R_F C_tot) where C_tot = C_F + C_det + C_amp_in

  • Output noise RMS: V_rms = e_out_density sqrt(BW) I_rms = V_rms / R_F

6.4 Tuning / commissioning steps (exact order)

  1. Layout & cleaning: ensure driven guard geometry is ready, clean PCB (isopropyl or flux remover), mount guarded resistor island.

  2. Build minimal TIA board: implement TIA op amp, R_F, C_F, driven guard but leave coarse & integrator disabled initially.

  3. Power check: apply rails, confirm op amp currents are normal.

  4. Short test: short detector to ground (or connect dummy resistor) and measure Vout offset; measure IB (or infer from Vout/R_F). If IB large, troubleshoot guard/cleaning.

  5. Set coarse VI = 0: ensure no large current injection; confirm Vout near zero.

  6. Test R_F gain: inject small calibrated current (e.g., via known resistor from a precision voltage) and verify Vout = I R_F. Check linearity.

  7. Tune C_F: apply a step current and observe step response; if ringing, increase C_F slightly (within 15 pF range). If too slow, decrease C_F.

  8. Enable coarse VI: adjust coarse pot until TIA output near mid-range (no saturation).

  9. Configure integrator: set integrator large (start at 3060 s), set clamps (so integrator can't rail), connect integrator through attenuation to R_fine.

  10. Enable integrator: observe TIA output drift slowly toward zero; integrator should stop when Vout 0 (null achieved). If it oscillates, slow integrator or add damping.

  11. Verify fine sensitivity: inject known pA-level current step and verify Vout 10 mV per 100 pA.

  12. Connect buffer & AA filter & ADC: sample at >10 fc and average to reduce noise.

  13. Long-term test: run integrator closed-loop for many hours; check integrator clamp usage and drift.

  14. Radiation & environmental tests (before flight): TID, SET/SEL, thermal cycling, vibration, vacuum; re-measure IB/noise post-tests.

6.5 Expected performance numbers (ballpark)

  • Sensitivity: 100 pA 10 mV.

  • TIA electrical BW: with R_F = 100 M and C_tot = 10 pF f 159 Hz (op amp GBW also matters).

  • Measurement BW choices: 0.1 Hz very low noise; 1 Hz faster but more noise.

  • Idealized noise (example): e_out_density ~1 V/Hz V_rms at 1 Hz 1 V I_rms 0.01 pA (ideal; practical will be larger due to resistor noise & leakage).

  • Realistic goal: I_rms << 100 pA (preferably 10 pA RMS in measurement BW).

6.6 Major pitfalls & how to avoid them

  • Surface leakage and flux residues: will create pAnA currents. Avoid by cleaning and guarding.

  • Poor guard implementation: incomplete guard defeats low-IB op amps. Drive guard at summing-node potential and surround the resistor island.

  • Wrong feedback resistor or poor mounting: low-quality 100 M will have high noise and leakage. Use specially made high-value, guarded resistor or guarded resistor assembly.

  • Integrator wind-up due to offset/drift: add clamps and slow integrator time constant; consider occasional controlled reset auto-zero.

  • Assuming COTS op amp is space-ready (LTC6268/ADA4530): these have great lab performance but are not space-certified. For flight, use space variants or plan radiation testing.

  • Overlooking op amp GBW & stability: ensure selected op amps have enough open-loop gain/GBW for the intended f_TIA.

6.7 Test checklist (copy-paste to lab sheet)

  • Verify guard drive follows summing node (oscilloscope trace).

  • Measure IB on guarded board vs temp (40+85C).

  • Calibrate R_F by injecting known currents and measuring Vout.

  • Measure output noise density; compute I_rms for BW=0.1 and 1 Hz.

  • Step response test: tune C_F for critical damping.

  • Enable integrator: verify null time and stability.

  • Inject 100 pA steps and verify 10 mV response.

  • Long-term closed-loop test (2472 h).

  • TID and SET/SEL tests for flight hardware; re-measure IB/noise post-irradiation.

  • Vibration & thermal vacuum tests; re-measure IB/noise.

Final presentable summary (23 sentences you can tell your guide)

We use an analog-nulling transimpedance architecture: coarse VI removes the ~750 A baseline; a 100 M TIA converts the residual to voltage (10 mV per 100 pA); a slow analog integrator injects pA-level corrections to maintain a nulled summing node; a low-noise buffer and anti-alias filter feed a 24-bit ADC. This preserves DC information, gives excellent SNR with narrow bandwidth, and is practical in space once we use space-qualified parts and execute the required guarding and radiation tests.

Short plain comparison what really matters for our case

  • If you need real-time or near-real-time detection (seconds or faster) of 100 pA steps on top of a 750 A baseline, the analog-nulling TIA is the most practical and robust approach.

  • Coulombmeter gives excellent raw sensitivity and is simple conceptually but it is slow and extremely vulnerable to leakage and charge-injection; it can be used for occasional high-resolution checks if the environment is tightly controlled.

  • A straight TIA (direct) would be simplest, but with the 750 A baseline its impractical unless you somehow remove the baseline elsewhere.

  • Dual-slope / charge-balance approaches are attractive for precision and drift rejection and are worth considering as a backup or hybrid (e.g., use TIA for fast detection and dual-slope for slow high-accuracy checks).

What we want to measure (explicit)

  • Quantity: change in photodiode current (I) caused by ozone absorption.

  • Target resolution: 100 pA steps must be reliably detected (i.e., distinguishable from noise).

  • Baseline: ~750 A DC photocurrent that must be rejected or nulled so the small I is measurable.

  • Time scale / bandwidth requirement: atmospheric / instrument changes are slow measurement BW can be narrow (0.11 Hz) to improve SNR. But we still want continuous monitoring and the ability to see changes on second-to-minute timescales.

Numeric practicality / examples

  • Using R_F = 100 M: 100 pA 10 mV. That is an excellent usable voltage for an ADC and easy to resolve even with modest ADCs (and trivial with 24-bit ).

  • Noise trade: integrated noise scales with BW. Using narrow BW = 0.11 Hz reduces rms noise dramatically essential for pA sensitivity.

  • Coulombmeter example: Cv = 1 nF, T = 1 s 100 pA 100 mV (great). But leakage of 1 pA over 1 s = 1 pC 1% error. So leakage must be 1 pA; thats hard in practice, especially in space (contamination, outgassing, radiation changes).

Final recommendation (short & direct)

  • Primary method Analog-nulling TIA (coarse VI TIA with R_F=100 M fine integrator/VI nulling buffer AA ADC).

    • Why: directly solves the huge baseline problem, keeps the TIA in linear range, gives continuous, fast-enough response, and provides excellent SNR when paired with narrow BW and good guarding.

    • When to use coulombmeter: as an occasional high-resolution verification mode or if you can ensure ultra-low leakage, long integration times, and safe, low-injection reset switches.

    • Dual-slope / charge-balance can be a strong backup for absolute calibration or long-term drift rejection.

An analog-nulling TIA subtracts the baseline with a coarse current, uses a 100 M TIA to convert the tiny residual to ~10 mV per 100 pA, and runs a slow analog integrator to null drift giving continuous, robust pA-level sensitivity while remaining implementable in space with proper guarding and radiation-qualified parts.

Section: Methods for Low-Current Measurement Comparison, Analysis and Recommendation

1. Introduction & measurement objective

This work requires measuring small changes in photodiode current (I 100 pA) that occur on top of a large DC photocurrent baseline (~750 A). The measurement must be continuous, reliable in a space environment, and compatible with flight qualification processes.

The challenge is therefore twofold:

  1. Achieve sufficient sensitivity to reliably detect 100 pA steps (signal noise), and

  2. Handle the large DC baseline so the front end does not saturate or operate outside linear range.

We review and compare candidate low-current measurement methods, evaluate their suitability for this application (including space constraints), and present the recommended architecture with engineering details and verification plan.

2. Methods surveyed (overview)

The following practical methods are compared in detail:

  1. Coulombmeter (charge integrator)

  2. Ammeter / shunt resistor (direct resistive conversion)

  3. Electrometer (voltage-mode measurement with ultra-low-bias amplifier)

  4. Transimpedance Amplifier (TIA direct)

  5. Analog-nulling TIA (coarse VI + TIA + fine integrator nulling) recommended approach

  6. Current-to-frequency / Dual-slope (charge-balance counting)

  7. Single-electron / single-charge detectors (listed for completeness; not practical here)

Each method is described, its governing equations are provided, and performance tradeoffs are analyzed.

3. Detailed descriptions, equations, pros & cons

3.1 Coulombmeter (Charge Integrator)

How it works (short): integrate input current on a capacitor CintC_{int}Cint for time TTT; measure voltage V=Q/Cint=(IT)/CintV = Q/C_{int} = (I\cdot T)/C_{int}V=Q/Cint=(IT)/Cint. Reset and repeat.

Key equation

Vout(T)=1Cint0TI(t)dt(for ideal integrator)V_{out}(T) = -\frac{1}{C_{int}}\int_0^T I(t)\,dt \quad (\text{for ideal integrator})Vout(T)=Cint10TI(t)dt(for ideal integrator)

For constant III: Vout=ITCintV_{out} = -\dfrac{I\cdot T}{C_{int}}Vout=CintIT.

Practical numbers

  • Example: I=100 pA,Cint=1 nF,T=1 sI = 100\ \text{pA},\; C_{int}=1\ \mathrm{nF},\; T=1\ \mathrm{s}I=100 pA,Cint=1 nF,T=1 s V=100 mVV=100\ \mathrm{mV}V=100 mV.

  • SNR improves with longer TTT (averaging), but leakage and 1/f noise limit gains.

Pros

  • Excellent sensitivity for slow signals (noise averages down as T\sqrt{T}T).

  • Simpler ADC requirements (larger swings from small currents).

  • Simple math and high linearity.

Cons

  • Periodic reset required dead time, switch charge-injection issues.

  • Vulnerable to leakage (op amp IB, capacitor leakage, PCB surface currents) that accumulate over integration period.

  • Dielectric absorption in capacitors errors, memory effects.

  • Limited bandwidth (update rate limited by integration period).

  • Difficult to guarantee in space unless switch, cap, and switches are qualified.

Space suitability

  • Possible if leakage is demonstrably << target current for chosen TTT and if switching devices and capacitors are radiation-tolerant. Risky due to charge-injection and leakage variability under radiation.

When to use

  • For occasional high-resolution checks or when very slow updates are acceptable and one can guarantee ultralow leakage.

3.2 Ammeter (Shunt Resistor)

How it works: current flows through shunt resistor RsR_sRs and produces V=IRsV = I R_sV=IRs measured by a voltage amplifier.

Key equation

V=IRsV = I \cdot R_sV=IRs

Practical numbers

  • For 100 pA detection using e.g. Vsignal=10 mVV_{signal} = 10\ \text{mV}Vsignal=10 mV: need Rs=100 MR_s = 100\ \text{M}\OmegaRs=100 M; this is impractical for many reasons.

Pros

  • Conceptually simplest, robust for large currents.

Cons

  • For pA detection requires extremely large resistances thermal (Johnson) noise and leakage dominate; also large voltage drops for big baselines.

  • Large R causes instability and huge area/mounting problems.

Space suitability

  • Not practical for pA detection with a large baseline.

When to use

  • Not suitable for this application.

3.3 Electrometer (Voltage-mode with Ultra-Low-Bias Amplifier)

How it works: measure the voltage across the sensor or at a high-impedance node with an electrometer amplifier designed for femtoampere input bias.

Key idea

  • Use an amplifier with input current IBI_BIB measurement currents; combine guarding and low-leakage mounting.

Pros

  • Can directly measure extremely small currents/voltages, DC measurements possible.

  • No reset cycles required.

Cons

  • Requires ultra-low IB amplifiers (fA), excellent guarding, and cleanliness.

  • Space qualification of such amplifiers is often not available; must be tested.

Space suitability

  • Possible if electrometer amp has flight heritage or is radiation-qualified and layout + guarding are implemented to flight standards.

When to use

  • If direct DC measurement is desired without nulling and you can obtain/qualify a space-grade electrometer.

3.4 Transimpedance Amplifier (TIA direct)

How it works: a feedback resistor RFR_FRF in an op amp converts input current to voltage: Vout=IRFV_{out} = -I\cdot R_FVout=IRF.

Governing equation

Vout=IinRFV_{out} = -I_{in}\cdot R_FVout=IinRF

TIA closed-loop electrical bandwidth (single-pole approx):

f3dB12RFCtot,Ctot=CF+Cdet+Cinf_{-3dB} \approx \frac{1}{2\pi R_F C_{tot}},\quad C_{tot}=C_F+C_{det}+C_{in}f3dB2RFCtot1,Ctot=CF+Cdet+Cin

Pros

  • Continuous real-time readout.

  • Simple concept; good linearity.

  • Fast when RFR_FRF and CtotC_{tot}Ctot permit.

Cons

  • If DC baseline is large, TIA output can saturate or require impractical output swing. Example: RF=100 MR_F=100\ \text{M}\OmegaRF=100 M, baseline 750 A Vout=75 VV_{out}=75\ \text{V}Vout=75 V, impossible.

  • Large RFR_FRF increases resistor noise and reduces bandwidth.

  • Requires ultra-low IB op amp and guarding for pA detection.

Space suitability

  • Good if baseline is removed or handled and components are qualified.

When to use

  • For direct current measurement when baseline is manageable.

3.5 Analog-Nulling TIA (Recommended)

How it works: combine coarse current subtraction + TIA + slow fine integrator that injects pA corrections to null residual current continuously.

Block flow

  1. Coarse VI (manual) subtracts large baseline (750 A).

  2. TIA with moderate R_F (e.g., 100 M) converts residual to voltage.

  3. Slow analog integrator senses TIA output and produces a corrected VI via an attenuator + R_fine (e.g., 10 M) that injects pA into the summing node to null residual.

  4. Buffer anti-alias filter ADC digitizes the measurement.

Key equations

  • TIA: Vout=IresRFV_{out} = -I_{res}\cdot R_FVout=IresRF.

  • Fine current: Ifine=Vatt/RfineI_{fine} = V_{att}/R_{fine}Ifine=Vatt/Rfine.

  • Null condition: Idetector+Icoarse+Ifine=0I_{detector} + I_{coarse} + I_{fine} = 0Idetector+Icoarse+Ifine=0 (summing node).

Pros

  • Solves the large baseline problem without extreme amplifier output or exotic resistor values.

  • Keeps TIA in linear small-range, maximizing sensitivity.

  • Continuous nulling handles drift and long-term offsets.

  • Measurement can be narrow-band (0.11 Hz) to reduce noise.

Cons

  • More complex than a single TIA: requires coarse VI stage, attenuator, R_fine, integrator tuning and clamp logic.

  • Integrator must be slow relative to measurement BW to avoid injecting control noise.

  • Guarding and component quality remain critical.

Space suitability

  • Strong candidate for flight because the architecture reduces component extremes. Using flight-grade op amps (space variants) and running qualification tests (TID/SET/SEL) reduces program risk.

When to use

  • Best for applications with large DC baseline and small changes (this project).

3.6 Current-to-Frequency / Dual-Slope / Charge-Balance

How it works: integrate current for fixed time then apply reference current of opposite polarity and measure time to return to zero (dual-slope), or convert current to frequency by integrating and discharging cyclically.

Pros

  • Very good drift rejection (dual-slope cancels offsets).

  • Digital counting provides high accuracy.

  • Often used in precision metrology.

Cons

  • More complicated control logic and timing.

  • Switching and reference current stability are critical.

  • Bandwidth limited by cycle time.

Space suitability

  • Viable; can be designed for flight with careful switch and reference current selection and radiation testing.

When to use

  • When absolute accuracy and drift rejection are critical; can be hybridized with TIA (fast TIA for detection, dual-slope for calibration).

3.7 Single-electron Detectors

How it works: specialized sensors/cryogenics to count individual electrons/charges.

Pros

  • Ultimate sensitivity (aA regime).

Cons

  • Extremely complex, generally impractical for this application (cryogenics, specialized sensors).

Space suitability

  • Not practical for present instrument.

4. Comparative analysis focused on our specifications

4.1 Requirements recap

  • Detectable change: I 100 pA

  • Baseline: I_base 750 A DC

  • Desired update rate: seconds to minutes (BW can be narrow; recommended 0.11 Hz)

  • Space constraints: parts must be flight-qualified or tested (TID/SET/SEL), guarding & assembly must meet space cleanliness and outgassing requirements.

4.2 Shortlisting methods against requirements

  • Ammeter/shunt: fails due to thermal noise and impractical R for pA detection. Reject.

  • Coulombmeter: viable for very high resolution but slow and vulnerable to leakage and switch injection could be used as verification mode but not primary.

  • Electrometer: possible if a space-qualified electrometer op amp is available; otherwise need qualification.

  • Direct TIA: impractical because of large baseline unless baseline removed.

  • Analog-nulling TIA: best tradeoff: handles baseline, gives continuous measurement, practical to implement in space with flight-grade parts. Recommended primary approach.

  • Dual-slope / current-to-frequency: good for calibration and drift rejection; consider as a secondary verification/calibration method.

5. Recommended architecture (final): Analog-nulling TIA detailed design

5.1 Block diagram (textual)

css
[Detector] > Summing node ( input of TIA)
             
[Coarse VI]    (manual pot driven transconductor to cancel ~750 A)
             
             
[FINE VI] <-- Integrator (slow) <--- Buffer <--- TIA output
             
             > TIA op amp: R_F (100 M) // C_F (2 pF)
TIA out -> Buffer -> AA filter -> ADC -> Telemetry
Guard amp -> drives PCB guard around summing node & resistor island

5.2 Component choices (prototype & flight guidance)

  • R_F = 100 M (precision, guarded), yields 10 mV per 100 pA.

  • C_F 15 pF (start at 2 pF, tune for damping).

  • Coarse VI: Vref 2.5 V 2.49 k + 10-turn pot transconductor op amp capable of 1 mA.

  • Fine VI: R_fine = 10 M; integrator output attenuated 1000:1 so 1 V integrator swing 1 mV on R_fine 100 pA.

  • Integrator : 10100 s (loop BW 0.010.1 Hz).

  • Buffer & AA filter: unity buffer (low e_n) followed by 2nd-order active LPF, fc = 0.11 Hz.

  • ADC: 24-bit , sampling at 10 fc and averaging in firmware.

  • Op amps (flight candidates): choose space-variant / SRH parts where possible for buffer & integrator (e.g., OPA4277-SP, ISL70227SRH). For TIA pick the best low-IB space-grade amplifier available (LMP7704-SP or equivalent) or plan a radiation test campaign if highest-performance COTS must be used for lab validation.

  • Guarding: driven guard amplifier, guarded resistor island, guarded coaxial cable for detector.

5.3 Control & limits

  • Integrator must include clamp limits (rails) to prevent windup and allow manual or firmware reset.

  • Provide test injection path for known currents (calibration resistor + switch).

  • Protection: small series resistor outside the summing node, transient suppressors far from the summing node (so as not to add leakage).

6. Tuning, verification & test plan (detailed steps)

6.1 Bench verification (order of operations)

  1. Assemble guarded PCB (summation node area small; guard copper driven to summing node).

  2. Power rails verification (check current, offsets).

  3. Short detector to guard; with coarse & integrator disabled, measure baseline Vout and infer IB using R_F.

    • Pass: IB 100 fA (preferred 10 fA) (if flight-grade parts used).

  4. Step response & C_F tuning: inject step current and adjust C_F to remove ringing.

  5. Coarse VI setting: adjust pot so Vout is centered (no saturation).

  6. Close integrator loop slowly: start with = 3060 s and verify Vout slowly goes to null without oscillation.

  7. Calibration: inject known small currents (e.g., 100 pA) and verify Vout 10 mV.

  8. Noise measurement: measure output noise spectral density; compute I_rms = V_rms/R_F for BW = 0.1 Hz and 1 Hz. Verify I_rms 100 pA.

  9. Long duration stability: record Vout with integrator closed for 2472 hours; observe drift and clamp hits.

  10. Environmental tests: thermal cycling (40C +85C), vacuum/dry environment checks, mechanical vibration. Re-measure IB/noise post test.

  11. Radiation tests (flight candidates): TID and SET/SEL tests; measure IB & noise before/after; determine if mitigation (shielding, redundancy) required.

6.2 Acceptance criteria (example)

  • Sensitivity: 100 pA 10 mV 10% confirmed.

  • Noise: Equivalent I_rms 10 pA (BW = 1 Hz) or 3 pA (BW = 0.1 Hz).

  • Null stability: residual after nulling 100 pA for at least 24 hours under thermal conditions expected in mission.

  • Radiation tolerance: IB & noise degrade less than X% (specify based on mission: e.g., <20% change) for mission TID; no destructive SEL.

8. Why the analog-nulling TIA is chosen (concise justification)

  • The analog-nulling TIA directly addresses the large baseline without requiring impractical amplifier output swing or exotic resistors.

  • It preserves DC information (we know how much is nulled and residuals), and provides continuous measurement with fast response capability while keeping high sensitivity through judicious BW selection.

  • It is implementable in space with space-grade parts and a clear qualification path; compared with pure Coulombmeter or COTS electrometer, it balances practical implementability and sensitivity.

9. Addendum: potential hybrid / enhancements

  • Hybrid mode: use TIA nulling for real-time monitoring and periodically switch to a coulombmeter or dual-slope calibration mode for ultra-low-drift absolute checks.

  • Digital assistance: implement periodic digital offset checks, logging integrator outputs, automated clamp resets, and radiation anomaly detection.

10. Conclusions & recommended next steps (for your report)

Conclusion: For detection of I 100 pA on top of a 750 A baseline in a space instrument, the analog-nulling TIA offers the best combination of sensitivity, continuous operation, and practical implementability. The method requires careful PCB guarding, space-grade/op-amp selection, and a concrete verification program (bench + radiation).

Next steps (practical):

  1. Build a guarded laboratory prototype (use best COTS electrometer amps like LTC6268/ADA4530 for noise floor validation).

  2. Implement flight-variant prototype using recommended space parts (e.g., LMP7704-SP / OPA4277-SP / ISL70227SRH or equivalent).

  3. Execute the verification test plan (IB, noise, step response, long-term drift, environmental, radiation).

  4. Iterate layout and component choices based on bench results, then finalize flight hardware.

Appendix (copyable test checklist for lab)

  1. Clean & inspect guarded PCB.

  2. With detector shorted and coarse/integrator disabled: measure Vout infer IB.

  3. Inject 100 pA known current verify 10 mV step.

  4. Tune C_F with step response.

  5. Enable coarse and set null within amplifier rails.

  6. Enable integrator at =3060 s and verify nulling behaviour.

  7. Measure output noise spectral density; compute I_rms for BW=0.1/1 Hz.

  8. Run 2472 hour null stability test.

  9. Environmental tests: thermal, vibration, vacuum.

  10. Radiation tests for flight candidate parts: TID, SET/SEL.
